item.title: Former WV state judge sues state after impeachment---HOLD
item.dc:creator: elowman
item.content:encoded: Robin Jean Davis, a former justice on the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia [judicial website], filed a complaint [text] on Wednesday in federal court alleging that the state violated her rights under both the US and state constitution when she was impeached. Davis retired during the impeachment proceedings. Davis and the three other active justices on the court were impeached by the West Virginia lower house last August for allegedly overspending on office renovations, inappropriately appointing senior justices and failing to establish proper spending policies.  Davis denies the allegations and asserts that even if they were true, they are not impeachable offenses. The complaint asserts the lower house "used these charges as a pretext to remove all four Justices on West Virginia’s highest Court so that the Governor could replace the popularly elected Justices with Republican men and create a 'conservative court' for years to come." Because Davis retired more than 84 days before the election, voters can elect her successor during a special state election.  If she had waited, the governor would have appointed an interim justice for two years.  The complaint said that this practice violated the Fourteenth Amendment voting rights of West Virginians. Davis alleges that West Virginia violated her freedom of speech rights because the charges she was impeached on were "in retaliation for her [liberal] political expression and beliefs." She also said her due process rights were violated when she was forced to retire in order to prevent the governor from appointing her replacement. The complaint also claims gender discrimination.  Davis asserts that the only male justice impeached faced federal criminal charges, while none of the impeached female justices were accused of a crime. She said that all of the replacements chosen by the governor were men. Davis also alleges violations of West Virginia's state constitution.

item.title: TEST #3
item.dc:creator: avayner
item.content:encoded:
On Monday the London High Court denied an application for a class-action against Google alleging the wrongful tracking, and subsequent sale, of millions of iPhone users’ data. The class of users from England and Wales, estimated to number over 5 million, was represented by Richard Lloyd before the court, whose claim against Google rested on an alleged breach of the Data Protection Act (DPA), which allows for compensation for the wrongful collection and distribution of personal data. The Court, however, disagreed that the action provided a legitimate basis for compensation under the DPA, citing a lack of demonstrable harm in the claimant’s application and describing its reasoning as “circular”: “[Claimant’s Application] asserts that the commission of the tort has caused compensatable damage, consisting of the commission of the tort,” distinguishing such a claim from past cases where an individual material loss or harm, such as emotional distress or loss of freedom, was put forward. Instead, the allegation claimed that Lloyd and the represented class were entitled to damages by the simple fact that Google had collected and distributed their data without permission:
The allegation is that the Representative Claimant and each member of the Class is entitled to damages “for [1] the infringement of their data protection rights, … [2] the commission of the wrong and [3] loss of control over personal data”
The Court held that while these facts may constitute proof of contravention of DPA provisions, they do not satisfy the second necessary element for a statutory right to compensation under the DPA, which is "as a result [of the contravention], the claimant suffers damage." Nor was there an argument by Claimant that the court should depart from such an interpretation of the DPA's provisions. Rather, Claimant's attorneys alleged statutory breach of duty under the DPA, but cited tort common law decisions as to why breach alone would qualify as sufficient damage. The judge rejected this approach, maintaining that a valid claim for damages under the DPA needed to be argued within the ambit of the statute itself:
...this overall approach is flawed. The term “damage” in DPA s 13 must be interpreted and applied in conformity with the language of the section and the provisions of the parent Directive. In general, the Court would give the term “damage” in the Directive an autonomous interpretation, that does not depend upon the content of individual national laws.

item.title: TEST: Federal Judge Finds that Trump Emolument Lawsuit has Standing
item.dc:creator: cgallmeyer
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge for the United States District Court for the District of Columbia refused [ruling, pdf] to dismiss an emoluments lawsuit against President Trump. Minority members of Congress brought the lawsuit, alleging that President Trump's continued business operations are violating the foreign emoluments clause [text] of the Constitution. The emoluments clause is intended to prevent foreign governments from gaining the favor of the federal government. President Trump sought to dismiss the lawsuit on four fronts: "lack of subject matter jurisdiction, lack of a cause of action, failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted, and the injunctive relief sought is unconstitutional." The Court's decision centered on the claim of lack of standing:
The President argues that this is an intra-branch dispute which does not belong in federal court because the plaintiffs' remedy is to convince a majority of their colleagues in both Houses to pass legislation addressing the President's ability to accept prohibited foreign emoluments.
The Court, however, sided with the plaintiffs, holding that the legislative process did not offer a remedy. Therefore, the plaintiffs did have the standing to file the lawsuit. All other motions to dismiss were deferred. This case is one of a few emoluments clause lawsuits [JURIST news archive] against President Trump.

item.title: TEST Emoluments Lawsuit Moving Forward Against President Trump
item.dc:creator: mbarber
item.content:encoded: On Friday, September 28, 2018, Judge Emmet G. Sullivan denied, in part, President Trump's motion to dismiss a lawsuit, filed last year by congressional Democrats, alleging violation of the US Constitution's Emoluments Clause [Cornell LII]. The Emoluments Clause prohibits any government official from accepting any present, emolument [Black's Law Dictionary], office, or title from any "King, Prince, or foreign State," without congressional consent. President Trump is represented by the Department of Justice. This ruling opens the door for discovery to begin, however the Department of Justice has requested the proceeding to hold pending an appeal of the decision.

item.title: New York federal judge allows lawsuit challenging law permitting public disclosure of firearm owner's addresses to go forward --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: lfares
item.content:encoded: [JURIST] Judge Kenneth M. Karas [court profile] of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York [official website] denied [RECAP docket] a motion to dismiss filed on behalf of the state of New York in a lawsuit challenging a New York state law that allows for the names and addresses of handgun permit holders in the state to be made public. Under the law [text], found in New York's penal code, "the name and address of any person to whom an application for any license [for a firearm] has been granted shall be a public record." In 2012, a New York used this portion of the law [New York Law Journal report, PDF] to obtain these names and addresses in Westchester and Rockland counties and used them to form online databases. Following public outrage, the database was later removed. However, following the Westchester and Rockland counties request, the newspaper sought these records from neighboring Puntam County. Puntam County originally denied these request, however, the state later compelled them to comply. The plaintiffs in the lawsuit are two individuals who had their names and addresses released in Putnam County. One plaintiff is arguing that his status as a gun owner is a private and personal matter that should not be made public. The second is arguing that although he intended on buying a firearm he never did so specifically because he would not want his information to be made public. Neither plaintiff are named in the lawsuit. State Attorney General Barbara Underwood's office filed the motion to dismiss the complaint earlier this year. Both plaintiffs brought claims alleged violations of the 14th Amendment right to privacy and their Second Amendment right to bear arms. Judge Karas stated that although the first plaintiff could not bring a Second Amendment claim as he already owns a gun, the second plaintiff could bring both as he is alleging the law directly impeded his ability to buy a firearm. As Judge Karas phrased it, he was forced into a situation where he had to protect his own privacy and sacrifice his Second Amendment rights or sacrifice his right to privacy in order to protect his right to a firearm. A conference before Judge Karas is currently scheduled for November 15th to determine where the parties will go from here.

item.title: Germany’s coalition parties agreed on a new immigration law on Tuesday to attract more skilled workers from countries outside the European Union, in a politically risky push to fill a record number of job vacancies and stabilize the public pension system.---DNP

item.title: Supreme Court hears case challenging federal sex offender registration law---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded:
The US Supreme Court [official website] heard oral argument [transcript] on Tuesday in a case challenging the federal Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act (SORNA) [Cornell, materials]. The case, Gundy v. US [docket], begs answers to two primary questions [text] resulting from SORNA's delegation authority to the Attorney General (AG): "[w]hether convicted sex offenders are "required to register” under [SORNA] while in custody, regardless of how long they have until release; and "[w]hether all offenders convicted of a qualifying sex offense prior to SORNA's enactment are "required to register" under SORNA no later than August 1, 2008." The petitioner, Herman Grundy, specifically challenges SORNA's delegation provision, saying it "grants unguided power to the nation's top prosecutor to expand the scope of criminal laws and to impose burdensome, sometimes lifetime registration requirements on hundreds of thousands of individuals." The statute refers to SORNA as a "comprehensive national system for the registration of [sex] offenders" but does not indicate that the statute applies retroactively to individuals convicted prior to the statute's enactment. Justice Gorsuch summarized the petitioner's argument, saying:
[T]he specific statutory section dealing with pre-enactment offenders says unambiguously that the Attorney General decides whether, how, when, and who, even who.  So you don't even know if you're going to be subject to this law … And … I'm having trouble thinking of another delegation in which this Court has ever allowed the chief prosecutor of the United States to write the criminal law for those he's going to prosecute. [This Court] say[s] that vague criminal laws must be stricken. [This Court] just repeated that last term. What's vaguer than a blank check to the Attorney General of the United States to determine who he's going to prosecute?
The respondent countered the argument, saying the statute provides for guidance in governing pre-statute offenders and vests the authority with the AG: "[The AG's] job is to get as many of the existing offenders who fall into that universe into the registries as you can, recognizing there are going to be some practical barriers. [He is] going to have to specify the applicability of the requirements." The Court began the 2018 term on Monday, hearing oral arguments [JURIST report] in two cases. The first concerning the Endangered Species Act [text] and whether it forbids an agency to designate private property as an “unoccupied critical habitat” if the land is not essential to species conservation. The second regarding the Age Discrimination in Employment Act [text] and whether it exempts state and local government employers with less than 20 employees.

item.title: TEST: ICJ rules in favor of Iran over US sanctions
item.dc:creator: cgallmeyer
item.content:encoded:
In an opinion [pdf] released on Tuesday, the International Court of Justice [website] ruled the US must lift some sanctions imposed on Iran. The ICJ held in favor of Iran on three issues [press release, pdf]. The ICJ possessed subject matter jurisdiction to settle disputes over the US-Iran Treaty of Amity [text, pdf]. Iran successfully argued that there were plausible claims of rights under the Treaty. And that the provisional measures recommended by the court would alleviate dangers to Iranian citizens while not violating rights of the US. To protect the humanitarian rights of Iranian citizens, the ICJ ordered [press release, pdf] the US to not inhibit the exportation of any of the following:
(1) medicines and medical devices (2) foodstuffs and agricultural commodoties (3) spare parts, equipment and associated services (including warranty, maintenance, repair services and inspections) necessary for the safety of civil aviation
Additionally, the court ordered that neither party escalate the situation further. This case stems from new sanctions [JURIST report] issued by President Trump in May of 2018. In response to Iran's suit [JURIST report], the US urged [JURIST report] the ICJ to dismiss the complaint.

item.title: TEST- Tennessee Three Drug Lethal Injection Protocol Upheld
item.dc:creator: mborges
item.content:encoded: The Tennessee Supreme Court ruled the plaintiffs in this case failed to show that the current lethal injection protocol in Tennessee was unconstitutional. The death-row inmates argued that the current three drug method violated the 8th amendment of the U.S. Constitution. This is the third time that Tennessee has upheld its lethal injection protocol. Since 2000, lethal injection has been the go-to method of execution in the state. The current three drug protocol was adopted January 8, 2018 and "calls for the administration of ... midazolam (a sedative in the benzodiazepine family of drugs) followed by vecuronium bromide (a paralytic agent) and potassium chloride (a heart-stopping agent)." This lawsuit was initiated when the state attempted to set execution dates for 33 inmates earlier this year. Procuring necessary drugs for lethal injections is difficult, so the state is likely to do all of its executions at once. Public opinion prevents companies from supplying these drugs to the state. Anti-death-penalty protestors previously persuaded a dutch company to stop providing a main lethal injection drug, forcing states to change to a less popular option. A previous Supreme Court case provided the grounds necessary to prove a punishment was cruel and unusual under the 8th amendment. The plaintiffs need to prove that the current protocol has a risk of extreme pain and that the risk is substantial compared with available alternatives. The plaintiffs successfully brought the suggestion of Pentobarbitol to the court but they were not successful as it is not available for use in Tennessee. Due to a lack of an available alternative, the Plaintiffs lost the case.

item.title: TEST: UK High Court dismisses suit against Google
item.dc:creator: cgallmeyer
item.content:encoded:
On October 8th, the UK High Court dismissed a data privacy violations lawsuit brought by iPhone users against Google. The suit arose from alleged violations of the Data Protection Act 1998 (DPA) from June 1, 2011 to February 15, 2012. During this time, the plaintiffs accused Google of violating the DPA by secretly tracking and selling data. Claimants sought damages of £750 per person. Google estimated potential costs to run between £1-3 billion. Google tracked the data through a mechanism called "the Safari Workaround." This allowed Google to use 'cookies' to track user data without users knowing. Google could then use the collected data to create targeted advertising. The court held that the plaintiffs did not have a claim for damages under the DPA because the bargain between Google and the users represented a consent for services bargain.
Such bargains do of course take place, millions of them, every day. But they do not involve the offer or payment of any money. On the contrary, the implicit bargain is that if the consumer consents to the acquisition and use of their personal data in the ways set out in the “privacy notice” or “cookie notice”, the consumer will receive something else of value, in the form of targeted or filtered communications, more likely to be of interest to the consumer than if consent was withheld. The only alternative on offer is the refusal of consent.
Even if the plaintiffs had a claim for damages, the court ruled that the claim could not continue as a representative action. The claimants lacked similar interest, a reliable way to figure out the number of claimants, and the court's discretion to allow the suit to continue. The European Commission fined Google earlier this year for unrelated privacy violations. In 2012, the Federal Trade Commission fined Google $22.5 million in a similar breach of privacy case.

item.title: TEST- Voter ID law upheld in Arkansas Supreme Court
item.dc:creator: mborges
item.content:encoded: On Thursday, contrary to a previous ruling, the Arkansas Supreme Court upheld a voter ID provision that was argued to impair qualified voters from casting their ballots. In Martin v. Kohls the court ruled that the previous, similar, voter ID law would disenfranchise voters. The Court ruled that Act 633 did not impose an additional qualification on being able to vote by requiring voters to show photo ID. Voters can show an ID that is up to 4 years expired, and still cast a regular ballot. If a voter does not have a valid photo ID the act provides the ability to cast a provisional ballot.  To cast a provisional ballot, the voter can "complete a sworn statement at the polling site, under penalty of perjury, stating that the voter is registered to vote in this state and that he or she is the person registered to vote." Additionally, the voter can cast a provisional ballot and later present a valid ID to the election commission by noon the following Monday to have their vote counted. The plaintiffs asserted that Act 633 was "not germane to the amendment and is not consistent with its policy and purposes," and that it violated the Arkansas constitution in imposing additional qualifications to be able to vote and impairing qualified voters from voting. The Court ruled against these points stating that public policy is for the General Assembly to establish, not the Courts. Many states are grappling with their own litigation regarding voter ID laws created to swing the vote in the direction of whichever party is in power.

item.title: Advocacy group files lawsuit alleging Department of Veterans Affairs withholding records---HOLD
item.dc:creator: elowman
item.content:encoded:
The advocacy group Democracy Forward [advocacy site] filed [complaint] a lawsuit on Thursday asking the court to compel the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) [government website] to comply with a request the plaintiff made under the Freedom of Information Act [government website] at the beginning of September. Democracy Forward requested communications, meeting minutes and other information regarding the "role of non-government individuals in top-level decision-making at the agency."  The VA has neither produced the records nor explained the reason for the withholding of records within the time limit of 20 business days.  The lawsuit reads:
By failing to respond to Plaintiff’s request within the statutorily prescribed time limit, Defendant has violated its duties under the FOIA, including but not limited to its duties to conduct a reasonable search for responsive records, and to produce all responsive, reasonably segregable, non-exempt information.
Democracy Forward is concerned [press release] about the role of Donald Trump's "Mar-a-Lago Council" in advising the VA.  The "Mar-a-Lago Council" is made up of non-government individuals who belong to the same private club as Trump. The case was filed in the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia [judicial website]. In August, VoteVets [advocacy site], a veterans' advocacy group, filed [complaint] a lawsuit alleging that the VA violated the Federal Advisory Committee Act [government website] which requires transparency for advising committees made up of non-governmental members.  VoteVets supports the more recent lawsuit brought by Democracy Forward.

item.title: UN Committee urges Saudi Arabia to end air strikes in Yemen---HOLD
item.dc:creator: elowman
item.content:encoded: The UN Committee on the Rights of the Child [official website] called on [report] Saudi Arabia to end air strikes in Yemen in order to prevent children from being harmed, in a report issued on Thursday.  The report also said that Saudi Arabia must "[p]rioritize the protection of children in all military operations in Yemen and take concrete and firm precautionary measures and prevent the indiscriminate use of force so that no more civilians, in particular children, are killed or maimed."  The organization wishes for an independent investigation into alleged crimes against children committed by Saudi Arabia in Yemen. The organization also told Saudi Arabia that it was "primarily responsible" for civilian safety in all of its air strikes. According to the report, airstrikes in Yemen have killed at least 1,248 children and injured at least 1,284 children since March 2015.  Around 20% of the civilian deaths have been those of children.  Saudi Arabia's blockades have also led to many Yemeni children, particularly orphans, being food insecure. On Tuesday UN rights experts called for [JURIST report] an investigation into the disappearance of a Saudi journalist.  In September UN experts asked for [JURIST report] continued inquiry into the Yemen conflict.  In August the UN reported [JURIST report] possible war crimes being carried out in the Yemen conflict.

item.title: Music Modernization Act signed into law --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: eslobe
item.content:encoded: The Music Modernization Act was signed into law on Thursday by President Trump. The act included the Music Licensing Modernization Act, Classics Protection and Access Act, and the Allocation for Music Producers Act. The Music Licensing Modernization Act addresses royalty payments from digital music providers. The act allows a digital music providers to obtain a "blanket license." The blanket license will be administered by a mechanical licensing collective. The collective will collect royalties from the digital music providers and distribute the payments to the artists. The collective can also audit the music providers to ensure that royalty payments are being made accurately. A musical works database will also be created by the collective that will identify musical works and their copyright owners. The Classics Protection and Access Act provides copyright protections for recordings before February 15, 1972. For recordings dated before January 1, 1923, the protections will only last until December 31, 2021. After which, the music will enter public domain. Recordings made between 1923 and 1946 will have copyright protections until December 31 of the 100th year after the date of recording. Recordings made between 1947 and 1956 will have copyright protections until December 31 of the 110th year after the date of recording. All other recordings before February 15, 1972, will have copyright protections until February 15, 2067. The Allocation for Music Producers Act provides a 2% royalty to music producers on licenses for transmission for music that was recorded before November 1, 1995. The law requires that the music producer, mixer, or sound engineer made a "creative contribution to the creation of the sound recording." Owners of the rights to receive receipts payable can object to claims for the 2% royalty. The music industry has faced many copyright challenges in recent years due to the advancement of technologies. In  2012, Japan updated its copyright laws to criminalize illegal downloading of copyrighted music and videos. China has been previously criticized for its lack of enforcement of copyright protections on digital copies of music. A lawsuit against YouTube for copyright infringement due to third party uploads of music artists songs was delayed in September due to the need for additional clarification of specific terms in the European Union law.

item.title: Israel Supreme Court stalls deportation of American student---HOLD
item.dc:creator: akoltonowski
item.content:encoded: Israel's Supreme Court on Sunday halted the deportation order of an American graduate student who has been refused entry to the country over her alleged activity on behalf of the boycott, divestment and sanctions (BDS) movement against Israel. Lara Alqasem, a University of Florida graduate student, has been held in detention since arriving in Israel on Oct. 2. Alqasem is enrolled in a one-year masters program in human rights at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. The request for a hearing by the Supreme Court comes after the Tel Aviv District Court on Friday rejected her appeal to be enter the country.  A 2017 law allows Israel to prohibit entry to BDS supporters and "Israeli authorities say that Alqasem’s college activism shows that she supports a boycott of Israel, and that the country has the right to deny her entry." The BDS movement is a "Palestinian-led movement for freedom, justice and equality. BDS upholds the simple principle that Palestinians are entitled to the same rights as the rest of humanity." The campaign works to end international support for "Israel's oppression of Palestines and pressure Israel to comply with international law."  The Supreme Court appeal is scheduled to take place on Wednesday.

item.title: TEST- Lawsuit filed with Kansas District Court to allow transgender individuals to change gender on birth certificates
item.dc:creator: mborges
item.content:encoded: A lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court of Kansas on Monday to allow transgender individuals to change the gender on their birth certificate. Lambda Legal, an LGBT rights organization, and a group of transgender individuals are suing the Kansas Department of Health and Environment, the State Registrar, and the Director of Vital Statistics. They seek to stop the "Birth Certificate Policy." It is alleged that having birth certificates that do not represent one's gender can cause unnecessary harm and exposure of sensitive information. A study found that, in Kansas, 24% of transgender individuals were harassed, denied service, or assaulted when revealing identification with a gender not matching their appearance. It is alleged that this policy violates the equal protection and due process clauses of the 14th amendment in prohibiting transgender people to freely express their identity and denying them the same right as cisgender people to have their correct gender on their birth certificate. Additionally, the plaintiffs allege that the first amendment is violated in forcing disclosure and violating transgender people's right to refrain from speaking. In Kansas, the Uniform Vital Statistics Act allows for this gender marker to be changed. Other agencies such as the Kansas Department of Transportation allow for gender to be changed on Drivers Licenses. The U.S. Department of State allows for gender changes on passports, the Social Security Administration permits a change in their records as well. The plaintiffs allege that not having a matching gender on a birth certificate and drivers license undermines the purpose of using those documents to verify identities. Additionally, that discrepancy constitutes an invasion of privacy, forcing transgender people to out themselves. Gender Dysphoria, the condition caused by living in discordance with ones true gender identity, is recognized by leading mental and mental health groups. It can have serious health consequences if left untreated. It can lead to anxiety, depression, and self harm. 47 states allow transgender individuals to change their gender, Kansas, Tennessee, and Ohio being the exceptions. All 3 of those remaining states have pending litigation against these policies.

item.title: Federal Court's green light on implementation of student loan assistance program stands---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: On October 16 2018, the US District Court for the District of Columbia denied [order, US District Court for DC] the California Association of  Private PostSecondary Schools'(CAPP) motion for preliminary injunction. This is the latest development regarding the federal government's implementation of the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program. On November 1, 2016, the Department of Education devised the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program. The program's purpose is to protect students from predatory educational loan practices.  The program prohibits educational institutions from forcing students to agree to enter internal dispute processes, as well as waiving their rights to class action lawsuits. The program requires educational institutions deemed "financially risky" to be prepared to accept losses due to government discharges of student loan repayments. The program also requires institutions to provide more transparent disclosures regarding the state of its student loan payments to prospective students.  Since the inception of the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program, CAPP has managed to delay the Department of Education's implementation of the program for two years. The situation changed following the intervention of a handful of interested student borrowers along with a coalition of 19 states and the District of Columbia. Back in September, this court ruled [article, JURIST] the delays in implementation were unlawful. The September ruling prompted CAPP to file for this motion for preliminary inunction. The Court held that CAPP, although had standing to bring its motion in court, failed to prove that it would suffer an irreparable harm if the preliminary injunction was not granted.

item.title: UK appeals court repeals "excessive" sentencing of anti-fracking protesters--HOLD
item.dc:creator: akoltonowski
item.content:encoded:
A London Court of Appeals on Wednesday overturned the "excessive sentencing" imposed on three anti-fracking protesters in Lancashire. The activists, Simon Blevins, Richard Roberts, and Rich Loizou, were convicted for causing a public nuisance for their role in a 100-hour blockade on a drilling site and were handed  a 15-16 month sentence. Lord chief justice, Lord Burnett of Maldon, called for the immediate release of the prisoners and said the sentences were "manifestly excessive."
“In our judgment the appropriate sentence was a community order with a significant requirement of unpaid work. But these appellants have been in custody now for two weeks, the equivalent of a six-week prison sentence. As a result, and only for that reason, we’ve concluded that the only appropriate sentence is a conditional discharge.”
The appeal was supported by the human rights organization Liberty and Friends of the Earth and the protesters were granted an expedited appeal amid widespread anger at the peaceful protesters initial sentences. During the appeal it emerged that the trial judge has family links to the oil and gas industry. "Judge Robert Altham’s father and sister run JC Altham and Sons, a company that acts as a supply chain for Centrica, which as invested tens of million pounds in fracking. The judicial conduct investigations office confirmed that it has recieved a complaint about Altham and will begin an investigation.

item.title: Brazilian Federal Police seek indictment of President on corruption charges --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: lfares
item.content:encoded: [JURIST] The Brazilian Federal Police (BFP) have asked the country's Supreme Court to indict current President Michel Temer on charges of corruption and seize his assets in light of the finding of the department's year-long investigation. The BFP's request also includes ten other individuals, including Temer's daughter, all of whom the BFP is seeking to have charged with corruption, money laundering, and racketeering. According to the BFP, construction and renovation workers who worked on Temer's home between 2013 and 2015 might have been paid with bribe money funneled through one of Temer's assistants. A Brazilian company has also allegedly admitted to paying over a quarter million dollars to Temer's assistants in exchange for political favors. The Supreme Court has stated that it will wait until the Brazilian Prosecutor's Office reaches a determination as to whether or not it will file a criminal complaint against the individuals before the Court decides how to proceed. The Prosecutor's Office will have 15 days to make its decision. Under the Brazilian Constitution, the Supreme Court will also need to get the approval of the Brazilian Congress before proceeding. However, commentators have noted that it is unlikely that the Court will obtain this approval as the Brazilian Congress has rejected calls for Temer to be charged on two occasions since 2016. Temer's office has refused to comment on the most recent accusations, which come just two weeks before the second round of the Brazilian elections. However, his lawyer has stated, that he has not yet been given an opportunity to look over the BFP's report. Temer is currently one of the most disapproved of Presidents in the country's history. He currently has an approval rating of five percent.

item.title: Trump administration asks SCOTUS to halt climate change case---HOLD
item.dc:creator: elowman
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration petitioned [application for stay] the Supreme Court of the United States [judicial website] for a writ of stay.  The writ of stay would halt the legal proceedings that a group of 21 young Americans and the advocacy group Our Children's Trust [advocacy site] brought against the US government for failing to adequately address climate change. The administration is alleging that that the plaintiffs are "asserting a new and unsupported fundamental due process right to certain climate conditions" and are focusing on "affirmative aggregate acts" rather than "challenging specific agency actions or inactions." The plaintiffs asked a federal district court in Oregon to order the defendants to implement a plan to remedy climate change.  The administration says such an order could violate the Administrative Procedure Act [National Archives]. On Monday the district judge said [JURIST report] the suit against the US government could move forward but could not name Donald Trump as a defendant.  The plaintiffs originally brought the suit in 2015 against the Obama administration but amended the complaint to include Trump. The case will go to trial on October 29.

item.title: Portuguese app store Aptoide said on Monday that a local court had ruled against Alphabet Inc’s Google in a landmark case, ordering the U.S. giant to stop removing its app from users’ mobile phones without their knowledge.---DNP
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded: On Monday a local court ruled against Portuguese app store Aptoide Alphabet Inc’s Google in a landmark case, ordering the U.S. giant to stop removing its app from users’ mobile phones without their knowledge.

item.title: UN expert calls for international investigation into the "evident murder" of Saudi Arabia journalist---HOLD
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded: UN Special Rapporteur David Kaye on Monday urged for all Member States to launch an independent investigation into the "evident murder" of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Earlier in October UN rights experts urged for an investigation into the disappearance of Khashoggi, a known critic of the Saudi government. Khashoggi was last seen by his fiancee on October 2, after entering the Saudi Arabian consulate in Istanbul.  Sources in Turkey believe that Khashoggi was killed in a state-sponsored murder after entering the consulate. UN experts held suspicions that Khashoggi’s disappearance and the allegations of Saudi Arabia’s involvement are related to his criticism of Saudi policies. According to Kaye, in order to establish a credible account into what happened an independent body needs to be formed; otherwise, "the facts will constantly be disputed." Kaye expressed his concern regarding the "rise in pressure on 'journalists", which is exemplified by the death of Khashoggi, as it is "emblematic of a broad kind of attack on freedom of information and journalistic reporting."

item.title: UK lawmakers vote to legalize abortion in Northern Ireland---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded:
The UK's House of Commons voted 203-123 on Tuesday to pass the Abortion Bill in Northern Ireland, which will reform criminal liability under the current abortion law. Bill sponsor, MP Diana Johnson, presented the Bill before the House of Commons in a 10-minute speech under the Ten-Minute rule for Private Members bills. If enacted, the legislation will:
[A]mend the law relating to abortion in England and Wales, and Northern Ireland; to remove criminal liability in respect of abortion performed with the consent of the pregnant woman up to the twenty-fourth week of pregnancy; to repeal sections 59 and 60 of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861; to create offences of termination of a pregnancy after its twenty-fourth week and non-consensual termination of a pregnancy; to amend the law relating to conscientious objection to participation in abortion treatment; and for connected purposes.
Tuesdays vote followed the first reading in the House of Commons. The second reading is set for November 23. The push for abortion reform in Ireland has grown insurmountably over the last year. Last month Ireland enacted the 36th Amendment of the Constitution, repealing the country's ban on abortions following a May referendum. The Bill repealed the 8th Amendment of the Constitution, which stated that "[t]he State acknowledges the right to life of the unborn and, with due regard to the equal right to life of the mother, guarantees in its laws to respect, and, as far as practicable, by its laws to defend and vindicate that right." In April the Belfast City Council in Northern Ireland voted 34-15 to decriminalize abortion upon requests from Amnesty International, Family Planning Association and Both Lives Matter.

item.title: Department of the Interior approves offshore oil refinery in Alaska---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: On Wednesday, the federal Department of the Interior announced [press release, USDOI] its approval for construction of an offshore oil production facility off of the Alaskan shore. The will mark the first offshore oil refinery located within federal waters. In fact, there are already four off shore artificial island oil facilities operating in Alaskan state territorial waters. "Working with Alaska Native stakeholders, the Department of Interior is following through on President Trump’s promise of American Energy Dominance. Today we’re announcing approval of the Hilcorp Liberty Project, which if completed, will be the first production facility ever located in federal waters off Alaska,” said U.S. Secretary of the Interior Ryan Zinke. Hilcorp's artifical island oil production facility project is referred to as the "Liberty Project". Approval of the project is part of the White House' initiative to encourage US energy independence and global competitiveness. Through the Department of Interior's Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, the Department of Interior engaged in a back and forth administrative process [administrative docket, USDOI] dating back to 1982. On behalf of the Department of Interior, the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management issued Hilcorp Alaska LLC a conditional approval. According to the Department, the plan was approved after following input taken from interested parties, such as local communities, tribal organizations, and other interested parties. "The plan was conditionally approved only after incorporating input from the public, and from North Slope communities and tribal organizations. As the project moves forward, BOEM will continue to work with Hilcorp to ensure all appropriate safeguards are stringently applied." "Using input from North Slope communities, tribal organizations, and the public, we have developed a robust set of environmental mitigation measures and safety practices that will be applied to this project.” , said Assistant Secretary Joe Balash.

item.title: Ecuador judge rejects WikiLeaks founder lawsuit over new embassy rules---DNP
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded: Ecuador judge Karina Martinez rejected a lawsuit on Monday filed by Julian Assange over the news rule imposed on him in the Ecuador embassy in London, which he has spent more than five years hiding in, arguing that the rules violated his "fundamental rights" and limited his access to the outside world. The news rules placed on Assange requires him to pay for some of his living expenses, such as phone, internet, laundry, food and medical bills; assume some cleaning responsibilities; and assume primary care of his cat. Assange alleged this was an attempt to force him to terminate his asylum in the embassy which could result in his placement in US custody. However, in support of her ruling, Martinez opined that the stricter rules imposed by the embassy do not violate Assange's asylum rights because "Authorities have the right to decide what is and isn't allowed inside the building." Assange plans to appeal the decision under the theory that these rules do infringe on his rights, stating that "The Ecuadorian state has an international responsibility to protect Mr. Assange." The WikiLeaks co-founder breached bail conditions and sought refuge at the embassy in 2012 to avoid an arrest warrant from the Swedish Prosecutor’s Office regarding two separate sexual assault claims. Although the rape investigation was dropped in 2017,  Judge Emma Arbuthnot upheld an arrest warrant for Assange in February for failing to appear at his bail address. According to Assange, he continues to reside in the embassy to avoid being jailed for violating the conditions of his bail, which could result in him being handed over to the US.

item.title: Federal court strikes down Wyoming 'Ag-Gag' law---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded:
The US District Court for the District of Wyoming [official website] on Monday struck down [opinion, PDF] recently enacted Wyoming statutes that impose criminal and civil penalties on individuals who collect data from private land or cross private land without the landowners permission. The laws, Wyoming statutes§§ 6-3-414(c) and 40-27-101(c), were enacted in 2015 to protect private resource data because the original trespass statutes did not account for such acts. Advocacy organizations filed the initial action alleging the statutes violate the First Amendment's free speech protection and Petition Clause, the Fourteenth's Equal Protection Clause, and that they were preempted by federal law. The district court initially upheld the first three counts for the plaintiffs and the Wyoming legislature amended the statutes to lessen the restrictions on access. Despite the amendments, the court held that the the statutes violated the First Amendment and ordered that they be permanently enjoined. The court rejected the government's argument that amending Wyoming's original trespass statutes to include a protection of resource data was not possible without infringing more on constitutionally protected rights:
[T]he government has not proven a strengthening of the state's trespass laws would not accomplish the same goals without infringing on protected speech ... They have failed to identify any reason why the curtailment of speech is "actually necessary to the solution "of the identified problem.
The court also denied the government's motion for summary judgment.

item.title: US judge orders extradition of man accused of murder in Guyana---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded: US District Judge Kiyo Matsumoto ruled Tuesday that Marcus Bisram who was wanted in Guyana on charges of murder could be extradited, denying his writ of habeas corpus pursuant to U.S.C. section 2241, upholding a previous ruling by Magistrate Judge Kuo. Bisram, at a party at his home in Guyana on October 31, 2016, is alleged to have approached the victim and touched his body, including his penis and buttocks. The victim is said to have rebuffed his advances and Bisram then commanded friends of his to "beat him to death." In his pleadings Bisram cited the ongoing case in Guyana, including the recantation of the main witness against him, that other witness statements were coerced and given under duress and that one witness who was sixteen years old and could not read or write could only put his thumbprint on his statement at his mothers direction and could not possibly know to what he was agreeing. He claimed that because of all these the Guyanese courts were considering dropping the charges. He also challenged whether the US could indeed extradite him because the treaty between the US and Guyana did not permit it. Judge Matsumoto found his arguments without merit. She could not find any substantial evidence to back up his claims of the witnesses recanting, or any of the other claims about witnesses, or the Guyanese courts dropping the charges against him. “Therefore, petitioner has not satisfied his burden to demonstrate that the charges against him have been dismissed, and his unsupported claim that they have been dismissed and that probable cause is therefore lacking does not warrant granting habeas relief,” Matsumo concluded.

item.title: Supreme Court hears oral argument on Alaskan National Park Service jurisdiction---HOLD
item.dc:creator: eslobe
item.content:encoded: The United States Supreme Court heard oral arguments [pdf] in Sturgeon v. Frost on Tuesday, a case concerning the authority of the National Park Service's regulatory control in national parks in Alaska based on the Alaska National Interest Land Conservation Act (ANILCA). The court heard oral arguments from Matthew Findley, who represented John Sturgeon, Alaska Assistant Attorney General Ruth Botstein, who argued in support of Sturgeon, and Department of Justice Deputy Solicitor General Edwin S. Kneedler. The case concerns Sturgeon, who was cited by the National Park Service for operating a hovercraft on a river on the Nation River in the Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve. Findley argued that ANILCA requires that the National Park Service does not have authority to enforce regulations on navigable waters within Alaska. Findley argued that the navigable waters are not owned by the federal government, and thus are not considered to be public lands. Botstein also argued that the navigable waters are not public lands and out of the reach of the National Park Service under ANILCA. Botstein stated that ANILCA intended the navigable waters to be out of the National Park Service jurisdiction because of the importance the waterways have for the transportation of people in Alaska. Kneedler argued that navigable waters within national parks are included in the definition of public lands. Kneedler states that the water itself was not conveyed to the state of Alaska, and thus would still be considered public lands. When questioning Findley and Botstein, the Justices focused on limits on jurisdiction of other federal agencies if the river is not considered to be public land. The Justices also asked questions regarding how Alaskan state owned lands are not considered to be public lands. When questioning Kneedler, the Justices focused on the limits on the National Park Service power if the the navigable waters were included in the jurisdiction of the National Park Service.

item.title: Scotland top court refuses to block Brexit case from going to EU court
item.dc:creator: lwinkels
item.content:encoded:
The Supreme Court of Scotland on Thursday ruled against the UK's request to appeal the referral of the case regarding the UK's ability to unilaterally stop Brexit. This decision will allow the case to be heard in the European Court of Justice (ECJ) in Luxembourg later this month. The ruling focuses on the rights granted in Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty and the European Communities Act of 1972. The key question is whether withdrawing from the EU under Article 50 will lead to altering the law without legislation. If this were the case, then the action would itself be illegal. The majority decision states that the 1972 Act made the "rights, duties and rules derived from EU law" into domestic law in the UK. The Act further created a new constitutional process for creating law within the UK.
[T]he fact that EU law will no longer be part of UK domestic law if the United Kingdom withdraws from the EU Treaties does not mean that Parliament contemplated or intended that ministers could cause the United Kingdom to withdraw from the EU Treaties without prior Parliamentary approval.
The court further stated that it was unlikely that the Parliament and the courts intended for ministers to be granted the power to remove the effect of the Act as the appellant party is claiming they are exercising. The court concluded that, while Brexit will require a change in domestic law, that change can only be made through Parliamentary legislation, as permitted by the UK Constitution. Therefore, the minister's action in withdrawing from the EU is political, not legal. The Majority also answered the question regarding Northern Ireland's assent to the referendum, stating:
The Lord Advocate and the Counsel General for Wales were correct to acknowledge that the Scottish Parliament and the Welsh Assembly did not have a legal veto on the United Kingdom’s withdrawal from the European Union. Nor in our view has the Northern Ireland Assembly. ... [T]he consent of the Northern Ireland Assembly is not a legal requirement before the relevant Act of the UK Parliament is passed.
Three Lords dissented from the majority opinion, arguing that the appeal should have been allowed.

item.title: Ex-Iranian minister arrested for financial fraud --- DNP
item.dc:creator: rmoore
item.content:encoded: The Islamic Republic News Agency on Sunday reported that Parviz Kazemi was arrested for financial fraud. Kazemi is Iran's ex-minister of welfare and social security. He was appointed by former President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad but resigned in 2006, a year after taking on the role. After his arrest,  Kazemi was allegedly taken to Evin Prison, a prison for political prisoners located in Tehran.

item.title: Florida judge denies Governor Rick Scott's request to impound all voting machines in Broward County---DNP
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded:
Chief Judge Jack Tuter of the Seventeenth Judicial Circuit of Florida on Monday denied Governor Rick Scott's request to "impound and secure" all voting machines in Broward County's elections headquarters when they are not being used to recount ballots in the US Senate race.
A recount of the Senate votes was ordered on Saturday after Scott marginally won against Senator Bill Nelson.
Tuter, however, denied such request and offered instead to add more security to guard the recounting process, which will begin executing their duties immediately, 24/7, until Thursday afternoon.
A security plan , agreed to by Scott and Broward Supervisor of Elections Brenda Snipes, to add three sheriffs to monitor the on-site surveillance cameras and the USB drives uploaded daily. Additionally, all deputies will report to the Broward Sheriff's Office Supervisor.

item.title: TEST- Emoluments Lawsuit Against President Proceeds
item.dc:creator: bbell
item.content:encoded: United States District Judge Emmet G. Sullivan decided on September 28, 2018 the court would consider further if President Donald J. Trump's accepted emoluments without Congressional approval. Connecticut Democratic Congressman Richard Blumenthal lead a case against United States President Donald J. Trump. In his opinion, Judge Sullivan explored the threshold question of whether this lawsuit has standing to bring a claim & how to characterize injury. The plaintiffs included 201 minority members of Congress who felt that the acceptance of emoluments were an abuse of Presidential power.  The President argues the dispute is between the branches of government and the members of Congress would be able to remedy the issue themselves by passing legislation to address the President's ability to accept emoluments, instead relying on the judiciary. However, Judge Sullivan rejected that argument and decided to proceed with the case.

item.title: TEST - DOES CONGRESS HAVE STANDING TO SUE THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded:
U.S. District Federal Judge Emmet G. Sullivan certainly thinks so. Ruling last Friday that members of congress can bring suit against the President of the United States for his allegedly violation of the Emoluments Act, where they allege that President Trump has accepted gifts from Foreign governments without first asking for their approval and subsequently accepting such gifts.
Lawyers for the president claim that the members of congress have other remedies at their disposal, including introducing legislation that clearly defines emoluments and whether they have the right to prohibits any and all emoluments, including ones unknown to Congress. In addition, the congress people bringing this action have ample legislative remedies at their disposal; they just don’t have the votes.
The congressmen are asking the court to declare a judgment in their favor stating the president has violated the Emoluments clause by accepting gifts from foreign states without first seeking congressional approval and also allowing them to prevent the president from accepting any present, emolument, office, or title of any kind whatever without the consent of congress.
This ruling sets in motion the opportunity for congress to challenge the presidents authority regarding whether he does have to consult them when he makes decisions.

item.title: TEST - Emoluments Suit against Trump by Congress moves one step closer
item.dc:creator: tzubizarreta
item.content:encoded:
The US District Court for the District of Columbia ruled Friday, September 28, that a suit brought by 201 minority Members of Congress could move forward after denying the President's motion to dismiss. The original complaint filed in June of 2017 alleges that President Trump has continuously violated the Foreign Emoluments Clause of the United States Constitution by accepting an unknown number of benefits for his businesses. The Foreign Emoluments Clause provides that "no Person holding any Office of Profit or Trust under [the United States], shall, without the Consent of the Congress, accept of any present, Emolument, Office, or Title, of any kind whatever, from any King, Prince, or foreign State." The complaint goes on to allege that by not requesting the consent of Congress, Trump is denying Members of Congress a constitutional right to grant or withhold their consent for the receipt of such gifts. Trump has taken a firm stance in opposition to Congress' interpretation of the Emoluments clause. The Department of Justice filed a motion to dismiss in September 2017 citing four different grounds for dismissal:
(1) lack of subject matter jurisdiction because plaintiffs do not have standing to bring their claims; (2) lack of a cause of action to seek the relief requested; (3) failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted; and (4) the injunctive relief sought is unconstitutional. Def.'s Mot. to Dismiss ("Mot. to Dismiss"), ECF No. 15-1 at 17-18.
The US District Court did not address all of these in its opinion, but chose to hear arguments and address what it saw as the "threshold question": Does Congress have standing to sue the President for denying them a perceived Constitutional right? After careful examination of precedent as well as argument from both parties, the court held that Congress did in fact have standing to continue the suit. The court rejected the President's argument that he had not denied Congress the right to legislate on emoluments but instead found that:
It is irrelevant that Congress can express its consent through legislation on the issue of emoluments or that it has done so in the past on limited occasions. In the absence of such legislation, the President deprives plaintiffs of the opportunity to vote every time he accepts an emolument from "any King, Prince, or foreign State" without the consent of Congress. U.S. Const. art. I, § 9, cl. 8.11
This finding along with key findings that Congress does not have adequate legislative remedies for this issue and that absent additional legislation, the burden of asking for consent is on the President led the court to rule that Congress did have standing to continue the suit. This case is still a long way from being decided, but the court took an important step forward in allowing the case to proceed. It remains to be seen how this will affect other ongoing lawsuits [JURIST Report] against President Trump's alleged violation of the Emoluments Clause. One such case [JURIST Report] has already been dismissed in New York as the US District Court for the Southern District of New York felt that it was really an issue for Congress to address. Congress is addressing it now and for the moment seems to have the court's favor.

item.title: TEST - Trump's motion to dismiss emoluments lawsuit denied
item.dc:creator: nchan
item.content:encoded:
A federal district judge has denied President Trump's motion to dismiss an emolument's lawsuit brought on by Democratic members of Congress. The President filed a motion to dismiss on the grounds that the plantiff's, consisting of 201 minority members of Congress did not have standing to in a federal court. However, the federal court ruled last Friday that members of Congress were personally and individually injured when their Constitutional right to vote on the President's acceptance of foreign emoluments were nullified. The Foreign Emolument Clause states:
No Title of Nobility shall be granted by the United States: And no Person holding any Office of Profit or Trust under them, shall, without the Consent of the Congress, accept of any present, Emolument, Office, or Title, of any kind whatever, from any King, Prince, or foreign State.
Under the Clause, federal officials, including standing Presidents, are not allowed to accept emoluments from foreign officials unless approved by Congress. The minority Congressional members believe that President Trump's financial interests abroad constitute a violation of the clause. Trump's failure to disclose his foreign business dealings and denying Congress the power to approve these emoluments amounts to the standing needed to bring the claim to a federal court. The President's legal counsel has argued that the lawsuit is an intra-branch issue that does not belong in a federal court and is beyond the subject matter jurisdiction of a federal court. The plaintiffs believe that their legislative role to resolve the matter is severely limited and the lawsuit requires a judicial order in order to get the President to comply with the clause. The Congressional members involved in this lawsuit contend that being able to legislate on the foreign emoluments the President accepts does not fully address the Constitutional rights entitled to each individual member of Congress and requires the Courts to address. The federal district judge ruled that the plaintiffs in this suit have standing in federal court by showing how the individual members of Congress have been injured by the President's actions, nullifying votes entitled to members of Congress under the Constitution and how a judicial decision can remedy the President's violation of the Foreign Emoluments Clause. The plaintiffs contend that their individual rights, as members of Congress, to approve the President's prohibited foreign emoluments were nullified in the past and will continue to be denied in the future without judicial action to force compliance from President Trump.

item.title: TEST-Federal judge:Congressional Democrats Have Standing to Sue President Trump
item.dc:creator: xshi
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge recently ruled that the approximately 201 Democratic members of Congress have standing to sue the President for allegedly violating the Foreign Emoluments Clause by accepting emoluments from foreign states without first seeking consents by the Congress.
Under the Foreign Emoluments Clause, "no Person holding any Office of Profit or Trust under them, shall, without the Consent of the Congress, accept of any present, Emolument, Office, or Title, of any kind whatever, from any King, Prince, or foreign State." U.S Const. art. I, §9, cl. 8.
The Democratic members of Congress in this case sought declaratory relief and injunctive relief prohibiting the President from accepting "Emolument" from a foreign state without obtaining “the Consent of Congress.”
The President acknowledged that his businesses receive funds from foreign governments. The President argued that that Constitution does not require him to seek or obtain Congress’ consent before accepting benefits arising out of exchanges between foreign states and his businesses; and the there was no subject matter jurisdiction because the members of Congress do not have standing to bring their claims.
After the Democratic members of Congress showing an ‘injury in fact’, a sufficient ‘causal connection between the injury and the conduct complained of, and a ‘likelihood’ that the injury ‘will be redressed by a favorable decision,’ the Court finds that the Democratic members of Congress have standing to sue the President for allegedly violating the Foreign Emoluments Clause.

item.title: TEST - The Emolument Clause Lawsuit and Trump's Motion to Dismiss
item.dc:creator: lwinkels
item.content:encoded:
A ruling by the federal court judge for the circuit court of ____ on the allegations brought against the President by 201 minority members of the United States Senate and House of Representative (CITE). These members allege that President Trump is violating the Foreign Emoluments Clause, which precludes him from accepting an emolument which is a 'salary, fee, or profit from employment or office (CITE) without receiving consent from Congress - ie. enabling Congress to vote on this (CITE). Justice Emmet Sullivan denied the President's motion to dismiss in part, and deferred the remainder of the issues alleged in the motion for further ruling.
In his defense argument, the President alleges four grounds for dismissal of the emolument case brought against him by members of congress. First, he argues that there is a lack of subject matter jurisdiction because the plaintiffs do not have standing to bring their claims, this is the major focus of the opinion and the case up to this point (CITE). Second, The President argues that there is a lack of a cause of action to seek the relief requested. Thirdly, there is a failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted. And finally, he argues that the injuncitve relief sought is unconstitutional (CITE).
The court addresses the first point raised by President Trump in the opinion, this is the main argument that it is concerned with and the one part of the motion to dismiss that is denied. The other three parts of the argument are deferred for further ruling.
To develop his argument that there is a lack of subject matter jurisdiction, President Trump argues that the plaintiffs have not met their burden to establish a judicially cognizable injury. He is arguing that the plaintiffs have not suffered ‘an invasion of a legally protected interest which is . . . concrete and particularized,'(CITE). The legally protected interest in this case is the right that members of Congress have to vote on and either approve or refuse the President's acceptance of emoluments. The plaintiffs are arguing that this right to vote has been completely nullified by the President's actions (CITE). The President however, argues that under the precedent of the case Raines v. ___ that “a foundational principle that the denial of institutional legislative prerogative is not a judicially cognizable injury.” (CITE). The court however finds the opposite, stating that this 'broad principle is not supported by Raines (CITE).' rather, this case specifically sets up that nullifying votes as the plaintiffs allege in this case is an institutional injury and thus they may have standing (CITE).
Court response to the President's arguments: they have standing to bring their claims: (1) they have adequately alleged a judicially cognizable injury that is fairly traceable to the President and can be redressed by a favorable judicial decision; and (2) although plaintiffs’ claims raise separation of-powers concerns, plaintiffs have no adequate legislative remedy and this dispute is capable of resolution through the judicial process (CITE).

item.title: TEST- UN orders US to lift Iran sanctions
item.dc:creator: bbell
item.content:encoded: On 16 July 2018, the Islamic Republic of Iran filed in The International Court of Justice against the United States of with regard to alleged violations of the Treaty of Amity, Economic Relations, and Consular Rights between Iran and the US. The treaty was signed on 15 August 1955 and entered into force on 16 June 1957. The Trump administration issued an executive order in August to reimpose stricter sanctions on Iran. The International Court of Justice is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations. The court settles, in accordance with international law, legal disputes submitted to it with binding power, and gives advisory opinions on legal questions referred to it. The court is composed of 15 elected judges. October 3, 2018, the court decided unanimously that the US should remove impediments of free exportation to Iran of medicines, medical devices; foodstuff and agricultural commodities; and spare parts, equipments and associated services necessary for safety in civil aviation. The US shall ensure that licences are granted and funds are unrestricted as they related to the goods and services. Also that both parties shall refrain from "any action which may aggravate or extend the dispute before the Court or make it more difficult to resolve." The court's decision was not a surprise to those who have warned the Trump administration of the unjust sanctions.

item.title: TEST - UN COURT RULES IN FAVOR OF IRAN AGAINST UNITED STATES
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded:
The International Court of Justice, The United Nations Highest Court, today ruled in favor of the Islamic Republic of Iran on it's July 2018 challenge of US sanctions against it, with regard to a 1955 treaty between the two countries which prohibited such acts.
The Courts ruling was narrow in that it dos not address fully Iran's claims against the US. The court addressed claims that it considered plausible in nature and "are of such a nature that disregard of them may entail irreparable consequences." These consequences the court said involved the citizens of Iran being exposed to dangers to health and life.
In it's claim Iran said the sanctions adopted by the US placed the citizens of Iran in jeopardy by depriving, it's civilian airlines from being able to acquire spare parts and other equipment for it's aircraft, including being able to access the associated services related to warranty and safety related inspections. Iran further stated that restrictions on it's ability to purchase goods for humanitarian needs, including food, medicines, including life saving medicines, and medical equipment could have a detrimental impact on it's citizenry and country.
The US invoked Article XX, paragraph 1, of the 1995 treaty which states that in limited instances the US can adopt measures to protect it's interests as it relates to “fissionable materials, the radio-active by-products thereof, or the sources thereof” and thereby the court has no jurisdiction. The court using the same Article XX, cited that if the two parties have already attempted to resolve their issue through diplomacy and it failed, that they do have the jurisdiction to rule on the matters brought before it by Iran, thereby implying in it's view diplomacy was tried and did fail.
The court also unanimously ordered both parties to refrain from actions that could exacerbate an already volatile situation.

item.title: TEST - UN High Court orders US to end sanctions on Iran preventing humanitarian aid
item.dc:creator: tzubizarreta
item.content:encoded:
The International Court of Justice at the UN ordered the United States to end sanctions preventing humanitarian aid and assistance from being provided to Iran. Specifically the court issued an order stating that:
The United States of America, in accordance with its obligations under the 1955 Treaty of Amity, Economic Relations, and Consular Rights, shall remove, by means of its choosing, any impediments arising from the measures announced on 8 May 2018 to the free exportation to the territory of the Islamic Republic of Iran of (i) medicines and medical devices; (ii) foodstuffs and agricultural commodities; and (iii) spare parts, equipment and associated services (including warranty, maintenance, repair services and inspections) necessary for the safety of civil aviation;
The court also ordered that the US will have to allow any authorizations, licenses, or payments and transfers of funds necessary to Iran's acquisition of these goods. Iran first brought a request for provisional measures to the International Court of Justice earlier this year on July 16 in response to the US sanctions issued May 8. The request was brought to UN jurisdiction under Article XXI, Paragraph 2 of the 1955 Treaty of Amity, Economic Relations, and Consular Rights between the United States and Iran which states that:
Any dispute between the High Contracting Parties as to the interpretation or application of the present Treaty, not satisfactorily adjusted by diplomacy, shall be submitted to the International Court of Justice, unless the High Contracting Parties agree to settlement by some other pacific means.
The US attempted to argue that its sanctions were provided for where the treaty allows parties to "take measures to address matters of national security", but the court did not find this compelling in the face of the humanitarian impact on Iran. The US also claimed that Iran had failed to demonstrate the "irreparable prejudice and urgency" necessary for the ICJ to intervene. Iran countered by highlighting the impact the US sanctions were already having on the acquisition of food, medical supplies, and civil aviation. The court found compelling urgency in Iran's argument to halt sanctions against those specific items. That said, the court also made it clear that this judgement does not indicate a finding that the Treaty of Amity has been breached, merely that the rights claimed must be protected until the parties can bring arguments on the merits of their case. The US will likely continue to argue that these sanctions [JURIST Report] were issued as a matter of national security in response to certain Iranian officials funding of various terrorist organizations including Hezbollah and the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps - Qods Force. Iran will continue to cite the economic and humanitarian effects [JURIST Report] of the sanctions. The court has ruled for Iran on the humanitarian necessities, but that may or may not provide the economic relief Iran is seeking. It is also worth noting that the court does not provide any enforcement mechanism for the order issued here.

item.title: Supreme Court agrees to hear Virginia gerrymandering case---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lfares
item.content:encoded: [JURIST] The United States Supreme Court granted a writ of certiorari in Virginia House of Delegates v. Bethune-Hill on Tuesday, a case concerning the drawing of voting districts by the GOP led state legislature. The lawsuit alleges that the electoral districts were intentionally drawn in such a way as to dilute the votes of minority voters. The matter was previously before the high court in the October 2016 term. At that time, the court upheld only one of the 11 districts at issue in the matter and sent the remaining back before the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia for further proceedings. Although the District Court previously upheld the map, the Supreme Court stated that the lower court did not sufficiently analyze the racial impacts of the map. This current lawsuit argues that the Virginia legislators ignored prior orders issued in the matter direct them to take a "holistic" approach to analyze the districts. The challengers noted that many of the district lines have not been changed from the last time the matter was before the court. Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring asked the Court not to take up the matter, claiming that the challengers lacked standing to appeal the matter. The Court responded by stating that it will examine the issue of standing when it hears the matter this term.  A ruling on the matter is due by the end of June.

item.title: EU and UK reach agreement on draft of Brexit agreement --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: lfares
item.content:encoded:
[JURIST] The European Union (EU) and the United Kingdom (UK) have reached an agreement on a draft of the agreement to withdraw the UK out of the EU. Commentators have noted that UK officials have noted that the agreement as of now is merely an agreement on the legal technicalities of the withdraw and the text of the agreement itself. The text of the agreement begins by noting that the Agreement must have the same legal effect under the laws of both the UK and the EU, meaning that the courts of either entity will be able to address any conflicts that may arise under the agreement. In the lead up to the drafts, one of the key provisions the UK sought was a "good faith provision" in the agreement. The UK argued for the provision's inclusion out of a fear the EU would retaliate against them for leaving the Union by taking harmful legal and political action. Many commentators in the UK also cited fears of the unequal power balance the EU will hold over the UK as they transition out of the Union. The current draft of the plan includes this sought-after provision in Article 5 of the plan, which states that:
The Union and the United Kingdom shall, in full mutual respect and good faith, assist each other in carrying out tasks which flow from this Agreement.
The plan also placed significant import on the necessity to "to provide reciprocal protection for Union citizens and for United Kingdom nationals, as well as their respective family members, where they have exercised free movement rights." Under the agreement, individuals that exercised their rights to move freely throughout the Union can continue to enjoy these rights for the rest of their lives so long as their move came before end of the transition period. For those that moved prior to the transition period, the agreement will provide those individuals with permanent residency in the UK or EU member state if they resided within the state in question for five years. However, individuals who travelled from the EU to the UK temporarily, such as EU students going to school in the UK, will have to apply for residency in the country under UK law if they are still in the country after the conclusion of the transition period. In regards to trade, the plan provides that all goods placed into the EU or UK market prior to the end of the transition period will be able to remain in the market until they reach their end users without having to satisfy any new legal developments governing trade in the two territories. Although commentators have noted that the transitition process could take up to five year, the Agreement currently has it  scheduled to end on December 31, 2020. The Agreement does however include a provision which will allow for an extension of the transition period so long as a petition to extend is made prior to July 1, 2020.

item.title: Brazil's president-elect plans to grant asylum to Cuban doctors---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: Far-right Brazillian President-elect, Jair Bolsonaro, announced his intention to grant asylum to Cuban "slave doctors" sent to practice in rural areas of Brazil, according to Reuters [courtesy, Reuters]. This follows Cuba's intention to withdraw its doctors from Brazil following derogatory criticism of the way the Cuban government treats its doctors. In his Twitter account [Twitter], Bolsonaro has been openly critical of the way the Cuban government handles the salaries of Cuban doctors' sent to practice in rural areas of Brazil. According to UK-based Cuba Solidarity Campaign [article, CSC], the Mais Medicos (More Doctors) program was incepted in August 2013. The program aimed to send Brazilian and foreign doctors, including Cuban doctors, to rural areas of Brazil to aid lower income populations. Bolsonaro's criticism of Cuba echoed those of the Foundation for Human Rights in Cuba. According to the Foundation [article, FHRC], the More Doctors program represents a instance of modern day slavery. Specifically here, the Cuban government was criticized for its "enslavement" of its own doctors while they practiced abroad. The Cuban government is alleged to have hoarded the majority of the doctors' salaries. That the movement of the doctors are strictly restricted. Finally, the doctors are accused of being instigators of pro-labor socialist causes, while being held as pawns of electoral cronyism in favor of the Cuban government as well as the Brazilian Worker's Party.

item.title: Maryland AG appeals voting map ruling to Supreme Court---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: The Maryland Attorney General's office filed a notice of appeal Thursday to seek Supreme Court review of Earlier this year, the US District Court for the District of Maryland threw out Maryland's contention. Similarly, the Supreme Court also declined to hear Maryland's contention that the federal mandate over Maryland to redraw its voting districts. In its Consent Motion to Stay [text] before the United States District Court for the District of Maryland, the Maryland Attorney General contended it not necessary for Maryland to redraw its voting district lines by October of 2019. Instead, the state included its own separate proposed order for the court's review.

item.title: Lawsuit against publisher of neo-Nazi site Daily Stormer survives First Amendment challenge.---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zuram
