item.title: Nashville police officer files discrimination suit against department---HOLD
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded:
A Nashville police officer filed a lawsuit on Friday against the Metro Nashville Police Department (MNPD) and its Commander alleging her First and Fourteenth Amendment rights were violated as a result of retaliatory actions being taken against for filing discrimination complaints and an interview exposing the "Code of Silence" in the department. Officer Monica Blake alleges that after filing discrimination complaints and a sexual assault complaint in 2016, the department and Commander Janet Marlene Pardue took retaliatory action against her, such as arbitrarily denying requests that were granted to white or male officers and imposing harsher punishments on her for infractions than on officers with more serious infractions. Blake also alleges that her advocacy of a Community Oversight Board, which would independently investigate police misconduct, caused many in the department to harbor ill-feelings toward her and to mistreat her. Blake exposed the "Code of Silence" in the department in an interview with Community Oversight Now causing the department to consider suspending her for violation of its social media policy. A section of the social media policy reads:
Protect the Department's reputation: What you say online is a reflection upon Metro Police Department...Inappropriate online activities that reflect poorly upon metro Police Department, its employees or service can result in corrective and/or disciplinary action.
According to the complaint, the policy "illegally prohibits its employees from speaking out on matters of public concern in a way that MNPD perceives as negative for MNPD." The Community Oversight Board was approved during midterm elections.

item.title: Israel high court rules interrogation conducted by Shin Bet not illegal torture---DNP
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded: The Israel High Court on Monday ruled that an enhanced interrogation conducted by the Shin Bet, also known as Israeli Security Agency, of Hamas agent Fire Tavish in September 2012 was not illegally torturous, finding it reasonable due to Shin Bet's having reason to believe Tavish had invormation that could prevent terrorist attacks. The Public Committee Against Tortute in Israel (PCATI), arguing on behalf of Tavish, claimed that the methods used by the Shin Bet in its interrogation of Tavish amounted to illegal torture, which in 1999 High Court case, was declared illegal. According to the PCATI, Shin Bet utilized various torturous methods, such as repeated beatings, threats, and unconformable positioning (like the "banana" position) throughout the interrogation. PCATI argued, supported by the decision in 1999, that the Shin Bet can never receive permission to use enhanced interrogation. The court, in making its ruling, considered Tavish's conflicting testimonies of force used during the interrogation and found his earlier testimony, which detailed permissible forms of physical methods used against him, to be more credible. The court also found that Tavish only underwent enhanced interrogation for a specified range of dates, and only after weeks of non-cooperative, in order for Shin Bet to extract information it believed Tavish to have regarding possible terrorist attacks. The court also noted Shin Bet's belief that Tavish possessed such knowledge to be credible because the information extracted from lead to locating weapons used by Hamas in past terrorist attacks. The court also furthered the reasoning of the "ticking bomb" standard offered as exception to illegal torture in 1999, stating that it does not need to be actually known when the terrorist attack will occur nor does it have to be imminent in order to qualify the use of enhanced interrogation permissible. Instead, the court declared that the agency just has to believe that it may not be able to prevent the attack in the near future if it did not immediately act. In December 2017, the same court denied a petition that challenged a lower court's ruling exempting national security agents from criminal investigation despite their uncontroverted use of torture techniques of a Palestinian detainee, finding that the petitioner failed to prove that the lower court's decision to close the criminal investigation was unreasonable.

item.title: Turkish president demands extradition of Khashoggi killers at G-20 Summit---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mmarotta
item.content:encoded: At the conclusion of the G-20 summit in Buenos Aires on Saturday, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan gave a press conference in which he demanded the extradition of the killers of Saudi journalists Jamal Khashoggi in the Istanbul consulate this October. "It's essential that these people are tried in Turkey in order to eliminate any question marks that the international community may have," he said. Further, he claimed that Prince Mohammed gave an "unbelievable" explanation for Khashoggi's disappearance which denied any Saudi involvement. This is the first time Erdogan has directly criticized the crown prince of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, who was also present at the summit. Earlier in the summit, French President Emmanuel Macron also questioned Prince Mohammed, but directly. Mohammed replied that the French leader was "not to worry." Turkey has joined the United States and several other countries in imposing economic sanctions against Saudi Arabia in response to the alleged cover-up of Khashoggi's murder. Erdogan himself has been criticized for denying the Armenian genocide and ordering monuments to it to be destroyed, as well as for the suppression of free speech and right of assembly under his presidency. "This transgression should not have occurred," said Erdogan in the press conference. "Extradition of [the perpetrators] must occur."

item.title: Michigan judge orders state's chief medical executive to stand trial for Flint water crisis--DONE
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded: Genesee County, Michigan, District Judge William Crawford ruled Friday that the State's chief medical executive, Dr. Eden Wells, will stand trial for criminal charges regarding the Flint water crisis, including involuntary manslaughter. Wells's manslaughter charge stems from her failure to stop the Legionnaires’ disease outbreak caused from the contaminated water. The contamination resulted in 12 total deaths and several illnesses. Attorney General Bill Schuette said Wells and others also facing manslaughter charges, knew about the spike in Legionnaires’ but waited too long to disclose to the public.   Wells was also charged with  misconduct in office, obstruction of justice and lying to a peace officer. Judge Crawford acknowledge the discrepancies in the evidence, but ultimately ordered that the final decision be left for the jury.  A host of Michigan state officials have been included in civil and criminal actions related to the Flint water crisis. In August,  a judge for the US District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan dismissed the state of Michigan and Governor Rick Snyder from a class action lawsuit concerning injuries resulting from the Flint water crisis, saying that government officials are given sovereign immunity under the Eleventh Amendment.  In June Schuette announced charges against five former Flint officials  for their part in the Flint water crisis, including Michigan Department of Health and Human Services Director Nick Lyon, who was ordered in August to stand trial.

item.title: Supreme Court grants motion in patent case---DONE
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded: The US Supreme Court on Monday granted a motion to dispense with printing the joint appendix in Return Mail v. USPS, which the Court granted certiorari to in October. The case presents for review the question of whether the government is a “person” that can proceed under the America Invents Act. The act permits a “person” who has been sued for patent infringement to challenge the validity of the patent through the Patent Trial and Appeal Board. Rule 26 of the Supreme Court Rules require a petitioner to make fifty copies of a joint appendix that includes relevant documents for the appeal, such as lower court opinions and trial transcripts. The rule allows for the court or parties to bypass the joint appendix requirement where the documents attached to the petitioners writ of certiorari and original court record are sufficient for the Court's consideration of the case. Ultimately, bypassing the requirement can save thousands of dollars in court expenses. The case is still pending a decision from the Court. In granting Return Mail's motion, the Court has agreed to rely only on those documents included in the original record and the appendix included in the petition for writ of certiorari. The Appendix includes the original civil complaint, statutory provisions, several lower court opinions, and the Patent Trial and Appeal Board's decisions.

item.title: German coalition nears abortion prohibition compromise---DONE
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded: The German governing coalition on Wednesday may have reached a compromise that will end the prohibition on doctors to advertise abortions. Section 218 of Germany's Criminal Code sets forth the general prohibition on abortion, which prohibits abortion as to the individual terminating the pregnancy and the individual receiving the abortion, but does not deem violations punishable by law. The advertising ban, codified in Section 219a of the Criminal Code, carries up to a two-year prison sentence for offenders. Specifically, the provision targets doctors in that it "prohibits offering, announcing, or promoting one’s own abortion services or the services of a third person or disseminating declarations of such a nature in public, in a meeting, or as written material." Wednesday's negotiations laid ground work for a reform that would keep the prohibition in place, but that would also allow doctors to inform patients that they offer abortion services. The legislature will consider detailed plans to reform the legislation beginning in January. The advertising ban went under fire last year when three gynecologists were charged with violating the advertising ban for including material about abortion services on their websites. Doctor Kristina Hänel appealed her conviction and €6,000 fine, saying it was her duty to inform women about all aspects of an abortion, including methods and risks, prior to undergoing the procedure. The court dismissed Hänel's appeal, saying the acts did not fall under the mandatory counseling provision of the law.

item.title: TEST - International Court of Justice rules for Iran in Treaty of Amity case.
item.dc:creator: lwinkels
item.content:encoded:
The UN International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled in favour of Iran on their allegations of violations of the 1955 Treaty of Amity by the United States (link ICJ ruling). The ICJ stated that the United States “must remove” sanctions that could stop food, medical supplies, and other humanitarian products from entering Iran (pg 6 of ICJ Summary). Iran's reasoning in bringing forward this complaint is in relation to the “decision [by the] United States to withdraw from the JCPOA [Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]” (ICJ ruling). Arguing that this withdrawal is related to the Treaty of Amity, and violates the rights that the treaty was put in place to protect. The ICJ ruling first established the argument of jurisdiction of the court under Article II of the Treaty (link to treaty p. 901). This jurisdiction requires that the court protect the rights set out in the treaty, (link to treaty p. 902). Under this decision, the court imposed binding provisional measures obligating the United States to “remove...any impediments arising from the measures announced on May 8, 2018” (link to those measures/JURIST article?). The ICJ introduced operative clauses from the ruling which explicitly outline the provisional measure to be taken by the United States (ICJ Ruling). These provisional measures are directly related to the three categories of food, medical supplies, and humanitarian products - as well as the necessary licenses and authorizations which are required to enable these products to enter Iran (ICJ ruling). On all other areas in which the U.S. has imposed sanctions, the ICJ has no jurisdiction, and the U.S. is able to enforce any sanctions that have been put in place (Cite?). Judge Cançado Trindade writes a separate concurring opinion, in which he enumerates his position on the ruling and his distinct reasoning for why the provisional measures should be taken. He further argues that;
[T]he 1955 Treaty of Amity between them refers, inter alia, to the obligation of each State Party to care for “the health and welfare of its people” (Article VII (1)); it also addresses the obligations of the two States Parties always to “accord fair and equitable treatment to nationals and companies” of each other, thus refraining from applying “discriminatory measures” (Article IV (1)). Stressing this point, it further refers to the obligation of the two States Parties to accord fair treatment to their “nationals and companies”, without discriminatory measures (Article IX (2) (3)). (para. 69).
However, as has been highlighted before (Cite to other JURIST articles), the ICJ has no power to enforce the ‘binding’ provisions that the court has imposed. As such the United States faces no judicial backlash for failing to meet the requirements that have been set out in this ruling.

item.title: TEST ICJ grants Iran's request to suspend re-imposition of US sanctions
item.dc:creator: mbarber
item.content:encoded:
Today, the International Court of Justice (ICJ), the highest Court in the U.N., issued an order [text, PDF] granting Iran's request for provisional measures, for alleged violations of the Treaty of Amity, Economic Relations, and Consular Rights ("1955 Treaty of Amity") [text,PDF]. Iran's request [text, PDF], filed July 16, 2018, was in response to the re-imposition of US sanctions [Executive Order, PDF] for Iran's alleged refusal to allow the International Atomic Energy Agency access to military sites, as well as two alleged 2016 violations of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) [text, PDF]. The US sanctions came immediately following the US withdrawal from the JCPOA in May 2018. Specifically, the ICJ held that the US sanctions violated Iran's rights, granted under the 1955 Treaty of Amity, to obtain medicines, medical devices, food, agricultural goods, and goods & services necessary to maintain the safety of civil aviation.
[T]he Court concludes that, at this stage of the proceedings, some of the rights asserted by Iran under the 1955 Treaty are plausible in so far as they relate to the importation and purchase of goods required for humanitarian needs, such as (i) medicines and medical devices, and (ii) foodstuffs and agricultural commodities, as well as goods and services required for the safety of civil aviation, such as (iii) spare parts, equipment and associated services (including warranty, maintenance, repair services and safety-related inspections) necessary for civil aircraft.
The order stated that the US "must ensure that licences (sic) and necessary authorizations are granted and that payments and other transfers of funds are not subject to any restriction in so far as they relate to the goods and services referred to above." However, the US is unlikely to honor the ruling as Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, announced in a press conference following the ruling, that the US plans to pull out of the 1955 Amity Treaty.

item.title: TEST Federal Court injunction preserves protected status for immigrants
item.dc:creator: cthompson
item.content:encoded:
A judge on the United States District Court for the Northern District of California has preserved the Temporary Protected Status of immigrants from El Salvador, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Sudan in a case decided on Wednesday. The ACLU and several other parties brought the complaint in March, following a series of announcements from the Trump Administration ending Temporary Protected Status for immigrants from El Salvador, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Sudan. The Trump Administration explained that this change in policy is due to its findings of improved conditions in each of these countries, rendering the special status unnecessary. U.S. District Judge Edward Chen issued a preliminary injunction, noting that the 300,000 people who currently reside in the US under this protected status would "suffer irreparable harm and great hardship" if they were removed under the Trump Administration's order. Judge Chen found that the injunction was further supported by the Equal Protection clause of the 14th amendment, because there is evidence that the decision to end TPS for these countries may have been fueled by racial prejudice. Cataloging a host of public remarks and tweets made by the president, Judge Chen concludes that there is sufficient evidence of animus against non-white immigrants to support consideration of the plaintiffs' claims. The court also cites evidence that the DHS construed its findings of the conditions in each of the countries with the goal of justifying the end of TPS:
"[T]he sequence of events leading up to the challenged decisions are irregular and suggestive of a pre-determined outcome not based on an objective assessment. The record evidence indicates that, after receiving Decision Memos from career DHS employees, higher-level DHS employees – i.e., the political appointees – were “repackaging” the memos in order to get to the President/White House’s desired result of terminating TPS."
The preliminary injunction took immediate effect on Wednesday and a further conference is scheduled for Friday, October 26th after which the case will be adjudicated.

item.title: TEST - 9th Circuit Judge Issues Preliminary Injunction Preventing End of TPS Designation for Four Countries
item.dc:creator: tdelorenzo
item.content:encoded:
On October 3rd, 2018 the United States District Court of Northern California issued a preliminary injunction preventing the Trump administration from ending Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for citizens of four countries. In March of 2018, the ACLU of Southern California filed suit on behalf of immigrants from Hatti, El Salvador, Nicaragua, and Sudan after the Department of Homeland Security announced that it was ending renewals of the TPS designations for the countries. The injunction prevents the administration from revoking TPS visas from immigrants currently residing in the United States under the rule. In his order, 9th Circuit District Judge Edward Chen described the removal of TPS designations as a "strong break with past practice". Immigrants from the four countries affected have held TPS status for a number of years. Hatti, the most recent country to be designated, was given the status after major earthquakes struck the country in 2010. El Salvador has held the designation since 2001, while Nicaragua and Sudan have held TPS designations since the Clinton administration. The TPS designation for each country is required to be renewed every 6 to 18 months by the Department of Homeland Security, and the decision to end these renewals led to the suit. In his order, Judge Chen stated that a preliminary injunction was necessary to protect the immigrants from "suffer[ing] substantial irreparable injury" until a final ruling could be issued. He further stated that the administration's change in criteria for renewing TPS designations violated the Administrative Procedure Act without explanation or justification. Finally, Chen cited public statements made by administration officials that he felt illustrated a coordinated effort against certain groups of immigrants as particularly troubling.
There is also evidence that this may have been done in order to implement and justify a pre-ordained result desired by the White House. Plaintiffs have also raised serious questions whether the actions taken by the Acting Secretary or Secretary was influenced by the White House and based on animus against non-white, non-European immigrants in violation of Equal Protection guaranteed by the Constitution.
Chen stated that he expects to "expedite trial and final adjudication on the merits without delay", so it is likely that the injunction will only be temporary, and a follow up court date has been set for October 26.

item.title: TEST California Judge Halts DHS Decision to Terminate TPS Designations for Four Countries
item.dc:creator: peckerd
item.content:encoded: On October 3rd, a judge for the United States District Court for the Northern District of California issued an order temporarily halting the Trump administration's decision to terminate Temporary Protected Status designations for Haiti, Sudan, Nicaragua, and El Salvador.  The termination of these designations would make 300,000 current TPS beneficiaries from these countries subject to removal from the U.S. The decision comes as a ruling in the case of Ramos v. Nielsen. The plaintiffs in the case are TPS  beneficiaries from the potentially affected countries who have lived in the U.S. for years. They challenge the decision and seek a temporary halt to its implementation until the merits of their challenge are considered. The plaintiffs allege that acting Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security Kristjen Nielsen, in deciding to terminate the TPS designations of the four countries, "changed the criteria applied by the prior administrations, and did so without any explanation or justification in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act." They also raise additional questions over whether the actions were influenced by the White House and "based on animus against non-white, non-European immigrants in violation of Equal Protection guaranteed by the Constitution." In the court's opinion for the case, U.S. District Judge Edward M. Chen of San Francisco agrees that these concerns are supported by evidence and bring into question the merits of the decision. Plaintiffs presented evidence that the White House put pressure on the DHS to end Temporarily Protected Status, and that "Notably, Acting Secretary [Elaine] Duke’s writings suggest that she, in her role at DHS, was largely carrying out or conforming with a predetermined presidential agenda to end TPS." Chen also considers the question of whether the decision is motivated in part by racial animus against non-white immigrants. He considers several of Trump's public statements and proposed policies, including his characterization of Mexican immigrants as criminals and rapists, his call for a complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States, and more germanely, his comments about "shithole countries" which were uttered in the context of a discussion of immigrants from Haiti, El Salvador, and African countries. Haiti and El Salvador are two of the four countries whose TPS status would be terminated under the new decision. Chen finds that this is convincing evidence of racial animus as a motivating factor for the decision, in addition to the fact that all affected countries are majority nonwhite. Chen writes that if the implementation of the Administration's decision is not halted, "TPS beneficiaries and their children indisputably will suffer irreparable harm and great hardship." He elaborates that a large portion of beneficiaries have lived in the U.S. for over a decade, or multiple decades, as TPS status from their countries of origin have been renewed repeatedly by previous presidential administrations. Many also have children who were born in the U.S. and have only lived there. Given the great harm that would occur as a result of the decision's implementation, and in light of the strong evidence in support of the plaintiffs' complaints on the decision's legal merits, Chen and the Court find that there is more than enough reason to warrant a preliminary injunction.

item.title: TEST-Federal judge granted preliminary injunction blocking Trump from terminating protections for immigrants
item.dc:creator: xshi
item.content:encoded: On October 3rd, a San Francisco federal district court judge granted a preliminary injunction enjoining the Trump government from implementing or enforcing the decisions of the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security(DHS) to terminate the legal status of approximately 300,000 Temporary Protected Status(TPS) beneficiaries from Haiti, Sudan, Nicaragua, and El Salvador along with their U.S.-citizen children. The federal judge Edward Chen found that, without a preliminary injunction, TPS beneficiaries are likely to suffer irreparable injury, including being uprooted from their homes, jobs, careers, and communities; being removed to countries to which their children and family members may have little or no ties and which may not be safe; be confronted with the dilemma of either bringing their children with them, giving up their children’s lives in the United States, or being separated from their children. The judge also found that the harms to TPS beneficiaries will also harm the public interest and will also negatively impact the United states from a foreign policy perspective. Some of these TPS beneficiaries have been in the United States for decades, and there is nothing in the record suggesting their continued presence threatens the national interest or national security. Rather, TPS beneficiaries are contributors to state and local communities. In this case the TPS beneficiaries have provided sufficient evidence to raise serious questions as to whether a discriminatory purpose was a motivating factor in the decisions to terminate the TPS designations. In fact, there is evidence of such as reflected by statements process made by President Trump before, during, and after the TPS decision-making: 1) In June 2017, President Trump stated that “15,000 recent immigrants from Haiti ‘all have AIDS’ and that 40,000 Nigerians, once seeing the United States, would never ‘go back to their huts’ in Africa.” 2) On January 11, 2018, during a meeting with lawmakers where immigrants from Haiti, El Salvador, and African countries were discussed, including with respect to TPS designations that had been terminated, President Trump asked: “Why are we having all these people from shithole countries come here?" In addition to the preliminary injunction, the judge Edward Chen also ordered that the federal government shall take all administrative actions needed to preserve the status quo pending completion of discovery and a ruling on the merits of the action, including all steps needed to ensure the continued validity of documents that prove lawful status and employment authorization for TPS holders.

item.title: TEST: Federal judge grants injunction blocking TPS removal of 300,000 immigrants
item.dc:creator: nchan
item.content:encoded: A federal district judge granted a preliminary injunction against the termination of Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for an estimated 300,000 immigrants from Haiti, Sudan, Nicaragua, and El Salvador. The plaintiffs, recipients of TPS, argue that President Trump’s announcement to end the TPS program in certain countries violates the Constitution’s Equal Protection Clause and were based on “animus against non-white, non-European immigrants." The decision to uproot TPS beneficiaries from the 4 countries were deemed not in line with procedural duties required in the Administrative Procedure Act. Judge Edward Chen’s granting of the injunction would preserve the status quo and grant TPS recipients temporary relief. In order to grant a preliminary injunction, the plaintiffs must prove standards including the TPS recipients suffering of irreparable harm, an imbalance of equities, and must be a benefit to the general public interest. Judge Chen reasoned that uprooting and removal of 300,000 TPS beneficiaries would potentially tear families apart and jeopardize the livelihood of their families. The children of recipients are heavily dependent on a parents as caretakers, breadwinners, and providers for their household. Sudden removal of would greatly harm the recipient along with lasting impacts on their household. TPS recipients are also an integral part of local and state economies, and TPS termination could potentially lead to a $132.6 billion loss in GDP, drawn from a strain on the health care resources, property taxes, and as members of the workforce. The federal judge argued that the injunction blocking TPS termination in these countries best serves the public’s interest. The immigrants living in the U.S. under TPS were all granted relief based on numerous events ranging from natural disasters to armed conflicts. The plaintiffs believe that the end of TPS to Haiti, Sudan, Nicaragua, and El Salvador were influenced by President Trump’s political agenda and discriminatory views against the countries and would violate the Equal Protection Clause. Looking to the President's comments about Mexican drug dealers as rapists and criminals, a travel ban targeting Muslim countries, and comments to lawmakers referring to Haitian and Salvadoran immigrants being from “shithole countries,” the federal judge took these into consideration when granting the injunction. The plaintiffs also presented evidence where the Department of Homeland Security Secretary and Acting Secretary were engaged in White House discussions to end the TPS program altogether. When announcing the end of status to certain countries the Secretary indicated that "[t]hese decisions along with the public statements will send a clear signal that TPS in general is coming to a close. I believe it is consistent with the President’s position on immigration . . . .” The government presented two legal arguments justifying their termination of TPS to the 4 countries including: “(1) Plaintiffs will suffer an irreparable injury only if they prevail on the merits and Plaintiffs are likely to lose on the merits and (2) Plaintiffs’ injuries “are inherent in the temporary nature of TPS status” The federal judge found that a temporary injunction is only meant to preserve the status quo, and is not a preliminary adjudication on the merits of the case. Judge Chen found that the government's reasoning was merely a dispositive assumption. Secondly, the inherent temporary nature of TPS was not reason enough to suddenly call for an end to the TPS program and accelerated removal of the 300,000 immigrants. The government is still required to follow APA procedures providing reasoning to an agency’s policy change. This would give those impacted a chance to wrap up their affairs in the U.S. without causing irreparable harm to the beneficiaries of TPS and the general public. Judge Chen has called for a Case Management Conference on October 26 to expedite the adjudication of the merits of the case.

item.title: TEST- UK COURT BLOCKS SUIT AGAINST GOOGLE OVER MISUSE OF USERS PRIVATE DATA
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded: The UK High Court on Monday ruled in favor of Google in a mass suit brought by Mr. Richard Lloyd in which he claimed that Google secretly tracked the internet activity of iphone users, then collected the data and sold it. "The Safari workaround" is the method that Google is said to have used to execute the claimed activity. Mr. Lloyd the only named claimant brought suit on behalf unnamed residents of England and Wales who were iphone users and could have been affected during the period of some months during 2011 and 2012, alleging a breach of duty imposed by the UK Data Protection ACT 1998 (DPA). If allowed the suit would have exposed Google to potential liability that if some of the claimant’s per capita figures for damages were accepted, would be between £1 and £3 billion, based on the approximately 5.4 million affected users. The court had two questions before it (1) whether the pleaded facts disclose any basis for claiming compensation under the DPA? and (2) if so, whether the Court should or would permit the claim to continue as a representative action? The court's answer was "NO" to both questions, because the Mr. Lloyd and the claimants he represented did not suffer damages under the meaning of the DPA, nor as a representative action under the Code of Civil Procedure rules CPR 19.6(1) (see [42-43], [82(1), 83-93]).

item.title: TEST- UK High Court dismisses claims against Google
item.dc:creator: bbell
item.content:encoded: This morning, claims against Google were dismissed by Justice Warby of London High Court. The subject of the claim was the "Safari Workaround" from 2011-2012 when Google secretly tracked the internet activity of iPhone users by collecting, using, and selling their information breaching the duty of the the Data Protection Act 1998 (DPA). The question at stake was whether there was basis for claiming compensation under the DPA and if the court would allow the claim to continue as a representative action. Richard Lloyd, the only named claimant, was seeking compensation for a Class of 4.4 million iPhone users damages. Reflecting the value of the data wrongfully mined by Google, the damage estimate was between £1-3 billion. The court held that the "damage" claim were unsupported in the DPA and that the claim could not continue as a represented action as the Class does not have the "same interest" and/or it is impossible to reliably ascertain the members of the represented Class. Furthermore, Lloyd failed to establish that the claim falls within the jurisdiction and therefore the court did not grant permission to serve proceedings on Google outside Google's US jurisdiction. Lloyd and Google You Owe Us said they will seek permission to appeal the judgement.

item.title: [Training] UK Supreme Court: Refusing to print pro-gay message on a cake is not discrimination
item.dc:creator: avayner
item.content:encoded:
A legal battle over a cake shop's refusal to print a pro-gay rights message on a customer's order came to an end on Wednesday, the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom finding no discrimination on the alleged grounds of sexual orientation. The case stemmed from a May 2014 incident when a Belfast cake shop refused to build a customized cake adorned with a "Support Gay Marriage" slogan. The business purportedly had no problem serving the individual customer, Mr. Lee, a gay activist, but felt that printing the message was incongruous with their Christian beliefs. Mr. Lee complained to the Equality Commission of Northern Ireland (ECNI) and received their support in bringing a claim against the Ashers Baking Company for discrimination based on sexual orientation, as well as political belief. Direct discrimination, as it is understood in UK law, is principally characterized by treating people differently because of their status in a protected class. The Court found no such treatment in this case:
the appellants did not refuse to fulfil Mr Lee’s order because of his actual or perceived sexual orientation. The objection was to the message on the cake, not any personal characteristics of the messenger
In sum, Ashers could not refuse products to Mr. Lee because of his sexual orientation or political belief in gay marriage, but the Court held that this was not the case here. Conversely, Ashers' owners had the right "not to be obliged to manifest beliefs" they did not hold, which would have been the case had they been forced to make the cake. The hearing came to the Supreme Court after a trial court judgment in favor of Mr. Lee and a failed appeal by Ashers' owners to the UK Court of Appeals.

item.title: TEST-UK high court blocks a mass privacy action against Google today
item.dc:creator: xshi
item.content:encoded: Today, the high court of UK dismissed the claims brought by Richard Lloyd, who on behalf of a class of residents allegedly have been affected by Google's breach of duty under §4(4) of the Data Protection Act 1998 (DPA) over some months in 2011-2012, to collect between £1 and 3 billion compensation for Google's collecting, collating, and using consumers' data by a method called "the Safari Workaround”. The court found that Google had a cookie known as the “DoubleClick Ad cookie” which would be placed on a device if the user visited a website that included content from Google’s DoubleClick domain. Google inserted the DoubleClick Ad cookie through the exceptions of Safari with the effect to enable the delivery and display of Interest Based Adverts without the user’s knowledge or consent. Google would sort different groups of people by the information they collected from browsers and direct their advertisements to the groups. Mr. Lloyd claimed that “The Representative Claimant and each member of the … Class suffered damage by reason of Google’s contraventions of the DPA and are therefore entitled to compensation pursuant to §13(1) of the DPA.” In this case, Mr. Justice Warby answered "No" to both issues as whether the pleaded facts disclose any basis for claiming compensation under the DPA; and if so, whether the Court should or would permit the claim to continue as a representative action. Mr. Justice Warby explained that (1) the facts alleged in the Particulars of Claim do not support the contention that Mr Lloyd or any of those whom he represents have suffered “damage” within the meaning of DPA, §13, the damage Mr Lloyd or any of those whom he represents suffered is not genuine quantifiable damage and there was no material, diminution in the value of their right to control the use of their information; and/or (2) the Court would inevitably refuse to allow the claim to continue as a representative action because the nature and extent of the breach and the impact it had on individual Class members will have varied greatly and it is hard to identify all class members.

item.title: TEST - UK Court dismisses data protection lawsuit against Google
item.dc:creator: nchan
item.content:encoded: A UK Court has blocked a legal suit against Google for monitoring the internet use of Apple iPhone users. During June 2011 to mid-February 2012, a “Safari Workaround” allowed for a “Doubleclick Cookie” to gather users’ browsing history and internet use to collate and sell to advertisers. The representative claimant, Richard Lloyd, alleged that Google’s tracking of internet activity was a breach of the Data Protection Act (DPA) and sought damages for the unconsented use of personal data, relying on Section 13 of the Act, which states, “...an individual who suffers damage by reason of any contravention by a data controller of any of the requirements of this Act is entitled to compensation from the data controller for that damage.” The issues the court grappled with is whether the breach amounted to recoverable damages under the DPA and if it did, whether the claim would succeed as a representative action issue under Civil Procedure Rules 19.6. Justice Warby found that there was indisputably an unconsented tracking of users internet usage from Google, but that the claimant failed to show how the he suffered any compensatable damage under the DPA. In fact, the judge argued that some users might have preferred their data be used by Google to receive better curated advertisements. Finally, the court noted that the claimant did not show how Google’s action would constitute a successful representative action issue. The UK Court argued that multiple parties in the representative action would not have the same interests or be entitled to the same binding judgement amount in damages, based on the individual facts in each case. Therefore, Justice Warby ultimately dismissed the case against Google.

item.title: TEST - UK High Court Dismisses Data Protection Suit against Google
item.dc:creator: tzubizarreta
item.content:encoded:
The Queen's Bench Division of the UK's High Court of Justice dismissed a class action suit against Google on Monday for allegedly gathering and misusing the private data of more than four million individuals. Richard Lloyd and a group called "Google you owe us" brought the claim earlier this year stating the following:
The claim alleges breach of the duty imposed by s 4(4) of the Data Protection Act 1998 (“DPA”). The allegation is that over some months in 2011-2012 Google acted in breach of that duty by secretly tracking the internet activity of Apple iPhone users, collating and using the information it obtained by doing so, and then selling the accumulated data. The method by which Google was able to do this is generally referred to as “the Safari Workaround”.
Under s 4(4) of the Data Protection Act of 1998, it is the duty of the data controller (in this case, Google) to comply with all protections established under the act. Lloyd and his group identified themselves and more than four million iPhone users between June 2011 and February of 2012 as members of class whose rights Google violated. Specifically, Lloyd and his group were seeking damages on three grounds: "[1] the infringement of their data protection rights, … [2] the commission of the wrong and [3] loss of control over personal data". The case presented Monday was for the court to determine whether the facts as pleaded provide a basis for recovery of damages under the DPA and if so, whether the High Court should or would allow this to proceed as a class action suit. The court examined these two issues separately but found both to be lacking. The court first examined the statutory language of the DPA and found that not all breaches will necessarily result in the award of damages. Instead, the court found, "The statutory right to compensation arises if (a) there is a contravention of a requirement of the DPA and (b) as a result, the claimant suffers damage". Using this as guidance, the court was unable to find damages in the form of material loss or emotional harm in Lloyd's claim. On the second issue of whether the court should allow the case to proceed, the court's greatest challenge was being unable to identify a class of persons to pursue the suit. The court found that this case could not continue on three grounds:
(1) The essential requirements for a representative action are absent. The Representative Claimant and the Class do not all have the “same interest” within the meaning of CPR 19.6(1). (2) Even if the Class is appropriately defined, there are insuperable practical difficulties in ascertaining whether any given individual is a member of the Class. (3) Further and alternatively, the Court’s discretion would in any event be exercised against the continuation of the action as a representative action.
The court could not find the representative class to have the same interests in this suit and found the challenges of identifying and providing compensation to such a class unrealistic even if the class could be defined. In particular, the court found Google's arguments persuasive here:
Google submits that the existence of a common grievance against the same defendant is not enough to satisfy the “same interest” condition. In particular, where the defendant is alleged to have damaged individual rights and interests, the representative action will be unavailable unless every member of the class has suffered the same damage.
Google argued that every iPhone user would have to have suffered the same violation leading to the same individual damages. The court could not find this to be rationally possible even if the identification of individuals could be achieved. Debate over data privacy and data protection has only increased in recent years as a result of breaches like this one and new legislation. The UK passed the Data Protection Act 2018 in May 2018 both to supersede this act and as a supplement to European Union's General Data Protection Regulation which took effect at the same time. Data privacy laws are continuing to take effect world wide and this case will serve as important precedent for their regulation and enforcement.

item.title: TEST - UK High Court Blocks Data Privacy Breach Claim Against Google
item.dc:creator: lwinkels
item.content:encoded:
The High Court in the United Kingdom (UK) in a ruling on October 8, 2018 blocked a claim brought by Mr. Richard Lloyd that Google through Safari violated the 1998 Data Protection Act (DPA) by collecting personal data from over 4 million iPhone users in the UK. Lloyd is arguing that under the DPA, Google is a data controller and that claimants should be able to recover compensation for the collection of personal data. If this claim is successful then a second question is asked of the Court; whether they will permit the claim to continue as a representative action? In the terms of this claim specifically, if the claimants are able to recover will the estimated 4.4 million claimants all receive compensation? The predicted costs to Google, according to the Court, for this compensation is between £1 and £3 billion for this number of claimants. The High Court in this decision has dismissed the claim outright, stating in note 54 that the plain meaning of the DPA section 13 outlines that;
[T]he statutory right to compensation arises if (a) there is a contravention of a requirement of the DPA and (b) as a result, the claimant suffers damage. The right is defined as a right to compensation “for that damage”. The infringement and the damage are thus presented as two separate events, connected by a causal link...In this respect, the statute faithfully reflects the language of the parent instrument. Neither is apt to characterise the contravention itself as amounting to damage
Under this plain meaning, the claimant has failed to establish the violation of rights protected by the DPA. Rather, the Court states that Lloyd has presented a case where damage was suffered by a loss of data, but that this loss was not a significant distress as understood by section 13 of the DPA, and thus that the claimants would not be able to recover under this Act. Further, the Court outlined in the opinion the three categories for allegations of damage: "[1] the infringement of their data protection rights, … [2] the commission of the wrong and [3] loss of control over personal data." and stated that the 'Particulars of Claim' did not address any one of these categories. The decision by the Court that the DPA does not apply to this lawsuit then renders the question of whether the claimants are able to recover invalid. As a result of this finding, the Court is able to dismiss the claim in its entirety. The Court also took the position that due to the sheer number of claimants estimated to be in 'the Class' for this suit, there was no way to determine or define the group. This makes the claim While Lloyd's claim was unsuccessful, the UK Parliament has amended the Data Protection Act in May, 2018. The overview of these amendments details how the new DPA has been put in place to keep the Act up to date with the digital age.

item.title: TEST UK dismisses action for secret data collection against Google
item.dc:creator: mbarber
item.content:encoded:
Monday, the UK's highest court dismissed a charge against Google alleging a breach of duty under the Data Protection Act of 1998 (DPA). The complaint sought between £1 and £3 billion, and alleged that between 2011-2012 Google secretly collected the private data of as many as 5.4 million Apple iPhone users in the UK. The action was filed in May 2017 by Richard Lloyd, a consumer protection advocate, on behalf of all citizens of England & Wales. The DPA grants, among others, individuals rights to prohibit using personal data in direct marketing and from using "data... in any way that may potentially cause damage or distress." The complaint details how Google secretly collected users personal information through the Safari web browser application. The Safari browser was equipped with a setting that ordinarily blocked Third Party cookies however, Google reportedly utilized an exception to allow its own cookie called "DoubleClick Ad cookie" to enable the delivery and display of advertisements on user's devices. This was not the first time Google has been sued for secretly tracking users internet usage in this way.
In August 2012 the company agreed to pay a US$22.5 million civil penalty to settle charges brought by the United States Federal Trade Commission (“FTC”) that it misrepresented to users of the Safari browser that it would not place tracking cookies or serve targeted advertisements to those users. On 11 November 2013 it agreed to pay US$17 million to settle US state consumer-based actions brought against it by attorneys general representing 37 US states and the District of Columbia. In addition, [Google] was required to give a number of undertakings governing its future conduct in its dealings with users in the USA.
The complaint failed to state that Google caused any real damage or distress as a result of the collection, a critical component of a valid claim under the DPA. The high court dismissed the charge on the grounds that "the breach of duty has caused neither material loss nor emotional harm, and has had no other consequences for the data subject." The opinion concluded, "the facts alleged in the... Claim do not support the contention that Mr Lloyd or any of those whom he represents have suffered “damage” within the meaning of [section 13 of the] DPA."

item.title: TEST Tennessee Upholds Three-Drug Execution Protocol as Constitutional
item.dc:creator: bsige
item.content:encoded: On June 6, 2018, thirty-three Plaintiffs, each death sentence-inmates, filed suit in Tennessee to challenge the constitutionality of the state’s execution protocol. On March 15, 2018 the Court set execution dates for two of the plaintiffs. Thereafter, plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint that identified the one-drug pentobarbital method as an alternative to the three-drug method. On July 5, two days later, the Tennessee Department of Corrections (TDOC) removed the one-drug method from its list of alternatives. It left only the three-drug protocol. A ten-day trial began on July 9, 2018. Trial court dismissed the inmates’ complaint for declaratory judgment. The Supreme Court of Tennessee, upon its own motion, assumed jurisdiction over the appeal. The Supreme Court Affirmed the trial court’s judgement. This case is set against a backdrop of litigation over the constitutionality of the death penalty as executed in Tennessee. Since 2000, the default method of execution in Tennessee has been lethal injection, as established in State v. Morris. In 2004, the method of lethal injection used was held to be constitutionally permissible (State v. Robinson). In 2005, the facial constitutionality of the protocol was examined (Abdur’Rahman v. Bredesen). Still, the injection method was held to be legal. In 2013, the TDOC adopted a one-drug method, using pentobarbital. In 2017, the court addressed the facial constitutionality of Tennessee’s one-drug lethal injection alternative. It was held to be constitutional (West v Schofield). In short, the Supreme Court found that the inmates failed to show the availability of their proposed alternative method of execution, the one-drug method using pentobarbital. For this reason, plaintiffs failed to establish that the three-drug protocol constitutes cruel and unusual punishment. The expedited appellate procedure has not denied the inmates due process, and they are not entitled to relief on their remaining issues. In Baze v. Rees, the US Supreme Court held that Kentucky’s three drug method, which is the same as TN’s old method, was constitutional and that the Constitution does not demand the avoidance of all risk of pain in carrying out executions. Addressing Plaintiff’s alternative method, the Tennessee Supreme Court looked to the United States Supreme Court in Baze to show that Plaintiff is required to show more than a slightly or marginally safer alternative. Plaintiff had to show both that the state’s method creates a demonstrated risk of severe pain and that the risk is substantial compared to the known and available alternatives. The alternative was unable to be procured by Oklahoma in Glossip despite good faith efforts. It is difficult to obtain execution drugs, so states must often use what they can. Plaintiffs claimed that the availability requirement should not apply to them because of discovery disputes and state secrecy laws regarding executions. This argument was not accepted because it would have required the establishment of a law that is not recognized anywhere else in the United States. Plaintiff also claimed that they were denied notice and an opportunity to be heard on the availability of an alternative method because the TDOC revised the protocol on the eve of trial. The Supreme Court of Tennessee affirmed the trial court, which found that this did not substantially alter the protocol for purposes of facial challenge. The theoretical availability of pentobarbital based solely on its status as an option in the lethal injection protocol prior to the revision would not have satisfied Plaintiff’s burden of proof. The setting of execution dates of eight capital cases before June 1 due to a shortage of drugs put plaintiff on notice that the three-drug method would likely be used. Plaintiffs also claimed that the 8th amendment does not require the demonstration of an alternative. The United States Supreme Court in Glossip rejected this argument. Plaintiff also contended what constituted availability. Citing Glossip, the Tennessee Supreme Court stated that availability merely relies on the ability of a state to obtain drugs with ordinary transactional effort. The Court was also unwilling to judge the reasonableness of Tennessee’s efforts to obtain drugs by the ability of other states to do so (See Arthur v. Comm’r Ala. Dep’t of Corr.) As such, the Court upheld the three-drug protocol.

item.title: TEST: UK Supreme Court rules in favor of baker who refused to bake a cake with same-sex marriage message
item.dc:creator: cgallmeyer
item.content:encoded:
On Wednesday, the UK Supreme Court ruled in favor of Northern Irish bakers who refused to bake a cake with a message of 'Support Gay Marriage.' Gareth Lee argued that the bakers, Daniel and Amy McArthur, violated his rights under the Equality Act (Sexual Orientation) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2006 (SORs) and the Fair Employment and Treatment (Northern Ireland) Order 1998 (FETO). Lee, who was represented by the Equality Commission for Northern Ireland, won lower court decisions against the bakers. The bakers then appealed on the grounds that the rulings violated their rights under the European Convention on Human Rights. The UK Supreme Court held that "neither the SORs nor FETO imposes civil liability on the appellants for the refusal to express an opinion contrary to their religious beliefs." In making its decision, the court focused on whether the bakers had discriminated against Lee based on his sexual orientation or political beliefs. Ultimately, the court decided that the bakers did not discriminate against Lee personally, but took a stand against propagating a message they did not agree with.
It is deeply humiliating, and an affront to human dignity, to deny someone a service because of that person's race, gender, disability, sexual orientation or any of the other protected personal characteristics. But that is not what happened in this case and it does the project of equal treatment no favours to seek to extend it beyond its proper scope.
The Northern Irish case is similar to a recent Colorado case, Masterpiece Cakeshop, Ltd. v. Colorado Civil Rights Commission, that progressed to the US Supreme Court.

item.title: TEST - Northern Irish bakery victorious in UK Supreme Court "gay cake" case
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded: The UK Supreme Court on Wednesday decided in favor of Mr and Mrs McArthur, owners of Ashers Baking Company of Northern Ireland for their refusal to bake a cake for Mr. Lee a gay man who wanted a cake to take with him to an event organised by supporters of gay marriage in May 2014. Mr. Lee first approached Ashers Bakery to bake the cake and Mrs. McArthur agreed, then subsequently refused offered Mr. Lee a refund because her conscience would not allow her to make the cake for him. Mr. Lee brought suit on the grounds of direct and indirect discrimination, citing the 2006 Northern Ireland Equality Act Regulations (sexual orientation) (SOR) and the Northern Ireland Employment and Treatment Order 1998 (FETO). The McArthur's appealed to the Supreme Court after loosing first in the County Court, and later at the Court of Appeals, citing that their rights under the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), which includes, "the rights to freedom of thought, conscience, religion and of expression, and the right not to be obliged to manifest beliefs one does not hold."  They said that neither the SOR or FETO was applicable to them because of these rights granted them by the ECHR. The Supreme Court agreed stating that Mr. Lee was not discriminated against because he was gay but rather it was the McArthur's being required to promote a message on the cake with witch they disagree, and could not be compared with someone being refused a job or service because of their religious faith or sexual orientation.

item.title: TEST- UK Supreme Court backs bakers who refused to make cake with pro-gay message
item.dc:creator: bbell
item.content:encoded: On October 10, 2018, UK Supreme Court found that the district court erred and grants permission for the appellants (Ashers Bakery) to continue their appeal against Gareth Lee. In May 2014, Lee, a gay man, ordered a cake through the Ashers Bakery Business "build a cake service" that depicted cartoon characters Bert and Ernie from Sesame Street with the phrase "Support Gay Marriage." The Ashers Bakery, owned by Daniel and Amy McArthur, initially accepted the order, but then contacted Lee claiming that the bakery was unable to produce such a cake in good conscious, due to the baker's religious beliefs. The bakery then issued a refund for £36.50. Lee brought a claim for direct and indirect discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation, contrary to the Equality Act (Sexual Orientation) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2006 and on grounds of political opinion, contrary to the Fair Employment and Treatment (Northern Ireland) Order 1998. The court's reasoning included that: there was no grounds of sexual orientation discrimination or employment discrimination because the bakery did not object to Lee because he was a gay man, but instead to the explicit message written on the cake. Also, the court found that inscribing the pro-gay rights message on the cake was contrary to the McArthur's rights to freedom of thought, conscience and religion (article 9) and to freedom of expression (article 10). They were not obliged to write a message on their product that they did not hold to be true. The Equality Commission, who supported Lee's case, issued a statement that “There is a concern that this judgment may raise uncertainty about the application of equality law in the commercial sphere, both about what businesses can do and what customers may expect; and that the beliefs of business owners may take precedence over a customer’s equality rights, which in our view is contrary to what the legislature intended.”

item.title: TEST - UK Supreme Court rules for bakery in gay marriage discrimination case
item.dc:creator: tzubizarreta
item.content:encoded: The UK Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that a bakery has the right to not produce a cake with the message "Support Gay Marriage". In May 2014, Lee, a gay man from Northern Ireland, attempted to purchase a cake from Ashers Baking Company, Ltd. Mr. Lee had previously bought cakes from the Ashers, but he was not personally known to the owners or the staff. Mr. Lee wanted to purchase a cake from Ashers' "Build-a-Cake" service which advertised that the bakery could produce custom cakes, but did not state any prohibitions of religious or political messages. Mr. Lee asked for his cake to be designed with "Bert and Ernie" of Sesame street who are widely seen as LGBT icons (though PBS recently denied the characters are gay). In addition to "Bert and Ernie", Lee asked for the logo of an LGBT organization Lee volunteers for named Queerspace and the words "Support Gay Marriage" to appear on the cake. The owner of the bakery, Mrs. McArthur, took the order but later called Mr. Lee to decline the order and refund the money on account of her religious beliefs. Mr. Lee made other arrangements for the cake, but then filed suit with the help of the Equality Commission of Northern Ireland for direct and indirect discrimination on account of sexual orientation. The county court found this to be direct discrimination both of sexual orientation and religious beliefs. The Northern Ireland Court of Appeal found the same direct discrimination and again turned down the opportunity to review legislation. The Attorney General for Northern Ireland then intervened and requested that relevant legislation be reviewed by the UK Supreme Court under the paragraph 33, Schedule 10 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998, but the Court of Appeal denied this as they had entered judgement before the order was drawn up. The UK Supreme Court opted to hear the case anyway writing "Accordingly we give them permission to appeal as the substantive questions raised are undoubtedly of general public importance, not only in Northern Ireland but also in the rest of the United Kingdom." The Attorney General appealed asking the Supreme Court to review this case under the Fair Employment and Treatment (Northern Ireland) Order 1998 "FETO" and the Equality Act (Sexual Orientations) Regulations 2006 "SORs". Under the Equality Act, direct discrimination is defined as "“a person (A) discriminates against another person (B) if (a) on grounds of sexual orientation, A treats B less favourably than he treats or would treat other persons; …", but the Supreme Court did not find any evidence the bakers had refused on account of Mr. Lee's actual sexual orientation, but rather the individual message he wanted to promote. Similarly, the court could find no political beliefs under FETO that the bakers were discriminating against, but instead only a refusal by the bakers to express political beliefs contrary to their own. The court found that the bakers absent knowing any religious or political beliefs would have refused this same message no matter the customer. The UK Supreme Court has identified a fine line here that there is a difference between discriminating against an individual person and as a business being required to promote a religious or political message. It will be interesting to see how this affects other ongoing cases of discrimination by businesses.

item.title: TEST - State of Washington’s Supreme Court rules death penalty is unconstitutional
item.dc:creator: ssundier
item.content:encoded:
The Supreme Court of the State of Washington has issued a unanimous decision that the state’s death penalty laws are unconstitutional. The decision is based on evidence that shows discriminatory applications of capital punishment. Since 2014, there has been a governor moratorium on the death penalty in Washington. Currently, eight individuals are sentenced to capital punishment in the state. This new ruling stems from an appeal from the murder conviction for Allen Gregory, who was convicted of aggravated first-degree murder in 2001 and was subsequently sentenced to death. Capital punishment triggered an automatic appeal process. Gregory challenged the constitutionality of his sentence against both the Washington state constitution (article I, section 14) and the US constitution (Eighth Amendment). The majority opinion, written by Chief Justice Mary Fairhurst, expressed that the death penalty has been “unconstitutional as administered, because it is imposed in an arbitrary and racially biased manner”. The court’s decision took note of both implicit and overt racial biases affecting sentencing decision outcomes against black defendants. The court drew from sources including Beckett’s analysis and conclusions as well as a commissioned statistical study, which evidenced that:
“special sentencing proceedings in Washington State involving Black defendants were between 3.5 and 4.6 times as likely to result in a death sentence as proceedings involving non-Black defendants after the impact of the other variables included in the model has been taken into account”.
Although Washington’s death penalty has now been invalidated, the court remains careful to respect that capital punishment is not unconstitutional per se. If state legislature chooses to draft and enact a statute permitting capital punishment in the future, it would need to overcome the issue of unequal and arbitrary application.

item.title: TEST Supreme Court of the UK sides with Christian Bakers in 'gay cake' case
item.dc:creator: mbarber
item.content:encoded: The UK Supreme Court issued a judgment on Wednesday in favor of a Christian Bakery who refused to provide a cake with a pro-gay marriage message to a customer. The Court issued its judgment after hearing oral arguments back in May 2018. The claim, brought by Gareth Lee, alleged discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, an alleged violation of the 2006 Equality Act of Northern Ireland. Additionally, the complaint alleged discrimination on the grounds of religious belief or political opinion, a violation of the Fair Employment and Treatment Order of 1998 (‘FETO’). The initial county court ruling stated that the Bakery owners, Mr. and Mrs. McArthur, did discriminate against Mr. Lee both on grounds of sexual orientation and on the grounds of religious belief or political opinion. That ruling was subsequently upheld by the Northern Ireland Court of Appeal before the reversal by the UK Supreme Court. The Plaintiff, Mr. Lee, requested a cake with the image of Sesame Street characters Bert & Ernie with lettering that read "Support Gay Marriage." After initially accepting Mr. Lee's order and payment for the cake, the McArthurs later refused, fully refunding the price of the cake and citing religious beliefs that preclude them from baking a cake that conveys a pro-gay message. The McArthurs successfully defended themselves by invoking their respective rights as described in the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and FETO. In applying this rationale, UK Supreme Court held that the McArthurs did not discriminate against Mr. Lee based on his sexual orientation, religious belief, or political opinion, but rather refused based solely on their objection with the message conveyed on the cake. Further, the Court noted that because the McArthurs refused based on the message, not the messenger, they were similarly protected under FETO and therefore not liable for the £500 in damages originally awarded by the district court. The May 2018 oral arguments in this case were recorded in four separate sessions, spanning 2-days, and may be viewed here.

item.title: TEST-UK supreme court supports Christian bakery owner in "gay cake" discrimination case
item.dc:creator: xshi
item.content:encoded: The Christian owners of a Northern Ireland bakery(Ashers) won their "gay cake" discrimination case on Wednesday. The owners of Asher, the McArthurs, were found guilty of direct discrimination in the trial court in 2015 and they lost the case on appeal in 2016. The Court of Appeal held that the owners' refusal to bake a cake iced with a depiction of the cartoon characters ‘Bert and Ernie’ and the words ‘Support Gay Marriage’ is direct discrimination, even though the refusal was based on their religious belief. Under the Fair Employment and Treatment (Northern Ireland) Order 1998 (FETO), discrimination in the provision of goods, facilities or services on the ground of religious belief or political opinion is prohibited. Under Equality Act (Sexual Orientation) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2006 (the SORs), discrimination in the provision of goods, facilities or services on grounds of sexual orientation is prohibited. In this case, the McArthurs' objection was to the message, not the messenger. "The McArthurs could not refuse to provide their products to Mr Lee because he was a gay man or because he supported gay marriage, but that was different from obliging them to supply a cake iced with a message with which they profoundly disagreed" said Judge Hale of the UK supreme Court. The UK Supreme Court concluded that neither the SOR and/or the FETO imposes civil liability on the owners for the refusal to express a political opinion contrary to their religious beliefs.

item.title: TEST - UK Court unanimously grants appeal for couple who refused to make a “support gay marriage” cake
item.dc:creator: nchan
item.content:encoded: On Wednesday, through a unanimous decision, the UK Supreme Court allowed for an appeal of a May 2015 verdict against Mr. and Mrs. McArthur, the owners of Ashers Baking Company. Mr. Lee, a volunteer for a LGBT community organization placed an order at Ashers Baking Company in May 2014 requesting the words “Support Gay Marriage” to be iced on a cake. A few days later, the couple informed Mr. Lee that they could not fulfill his order based on their Christian beliefs objecting to gay marriage. After filing a complaint with the Equality Commission of Northern Ireland (ECNI), Mr. Lee brought legal action against the McArthurs on the grounds that he was discriminated for his sexual orientation. A district judge agreed with Mr. Lee and found that the McArthurs violated the 2006 Equality Act (Sexual Orientation) Regulations of Northern Ireland. The McArthurs filed an appeal against the decision.The five judges believed that the couple was entitled to their religious freedoms. The Courts reasoned that the McArthur did not know of Mr. Lee’s sexual orientation or political beliefs and would have denied the same cake request from a hetero-sexual customer. ECNI argued on behalf of Mr. Lee that his political beliefs were targeted when the McArthurs cancelled his cake order. The judges countered that political beliefs are not inherently tied to an individual's orientation and that a person of any sexual orientation could have requested the same message supporting gay marriage. The judges looked to records of gay employees on staff and other gay clients Ashers Baking Company had served in the past. The UK court ultimately granted the appeal to protect the McArthurs religious beliefs objecting to gay marriage, not to Mr. Lee himself.

item.title: TEST - Washington Supreme Court rules death penalty unconstitutional
item.dc:creator: cthompson
item.content:encoded: The Washington Supreme Court issued a unanimous en banc ruling striking down the state's death penalty law on Thursday. The court declined to speak to the constitutionality of the death penalty overall, and instead focused its decision on the state's death penalty law and the extent to which it is arbitrarily applied. The court reviewed the sentence of Allen Gregory, who was convicted of rape, robbery, and murder and sentenced to death in 2001. As a result of the court's decision, Mr. Gregory's sentence, as well as all other death sentences in Washington, has now been commuted to life imprisonment. The court determined that Washington's death penalty is "administered in an arbitrary and racially biased manner" and is thus unconstitutional under Washington's constitution. After citing statistical evidence of the doctrine's arbitrary application, Chief Justice Fairhurst, writing for the majority, also stated that "it logically follows that the death penalty fails to serve penological goals" such as retribution and deterrence. All of the justices concurred with the Chief Justice's opinion, and Justice Johnson issued a concurrence, expanding the basis for the law's unconstitutionality. This decision comes within a wave of national conversation surrounding capital punishment, which has led to different results in different jurisdictions. Most recently, Ohio evaluated its capital punishment law in April, and ultimately upheld it as constitutional.

item.title: TEST Washington State Supreme Court strikes down death penalty
item.dc:creator: tdelorenzo
item.content:encoded:
The Supreme Court of Washington state struck down the state's death penalty on Thursday, stating that it was "imposed in an arbitrary and racially biased manner" that violated the state's constitution. In the unanimous decision, the Supreme Court addressed issues raised by defendant Allen Gregory, who contended that the state's capital punishment statute was prejudiced against minority defendants and represented a disproportionate punishment for his crime. Gregory was convicted and sentenced to death for aggravated first degree murder for his 1996 rape and killing of Geneine Harshfield. Though Washington State has had a moratorium on the administration of the death penalty imposed by the governor since 2014, the ruling today ends the imposition of capital punishment in the state under the current procedural system entirely. There are currently eight inmates on Washington's death row, the sentences of whom will all be converted to life imprisonment. Chief Justice Mary Fairhurst wrote in the majority decision that the state's capital punishment provision "lacked fundamental fairness" in its implementation. The court extensively cited the work of University of Washington professor Katherine Beckett, who wrote on the statistically significant disparity in the treatment of minority defendants facing death penalty charges. Beckett found that:
"from December 1981 through May of 2014, special sentencing proceedings in Washington State involving Black defendants were between 3.5 and 4.6 times as likely to result in a death sentence as proceedings involving non-Black defendants after the impact of the other variables included in the model has been taken into account."
From this data, the court ruled that there were "fundamental issues" with the administration of the death penalty in the state, and declared its implementation unconstitutional. Though the ruling effectively ends capital punishment in the state for now, the court did concede that the death penalty itself is not unconstitutional, and that a fairly administered system could pass constitutional muster in the future.

item.title: TEST - Washington state Supreme Court strikes down death penalty
item.dc:creator: peckerd
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court for the state of Washington has ruled that the state's death penalty is unconstitutional. The unanimous ruling was made Thursday morning in the case of State v. Gregory. The majority opinion states that the death penalty in Washington is administered in a racially biased and arbitrary manner and does not serve any legitimate penological goal. The case in question comes from a re-appeal by Allen Eugene Gregory, who in 2001 was convicted of first degree murder and sentenced to death. Gregory had appealed his conviction once before but was re-sentenced to death. In the majority opinion Chief Justice Mary Fairhurst concludes, based on newly available evidence, that Washington's death penalty is imposed in an arbitrary and racially biased manner.  The opinion partially draws on statistical analysis which shows that cases involving black defendants were between 3.5 and 4.6 times more likely to result in a death sentence than similar ones involving non-black defendants. This leads the Court to conclude that the penalty lacks "fundamental fairness" and thus violates Article 1, Section 14 of the state's Constitution. Because of the arbitrary and biased nature of the punishment's implementation, the Court also concludes that the state's death penalty serves no penological purpose.  Because there is "'no meaningful basis for distinguishing the few cases in which [the death penalty] is imposed from the many cases in which it is not,'" the penalty fails to act both as a consistent retributive punishment for serious crimes and as an effective deterrent for future crimes. The Court declined to reconsider Gregory's arguments pertaining to the guilt phase of his trial. However, his and all other death sentences in the state of Washington will be converted to life sentences as a result of the ruling.

item.title: TEST - Arkansas supreme court decision upholding voter id law
item.dc:creator: lwinkels
item.content:encoded:
In a decision on Thursday the Arkansas Supreme Court upheld Act 633 a 2017 voter id law replacing the unconstitutional 2014 law of the same nature. This decision to uphold Act 633 also amended section 13 of amendment 51 which was a part of this bill as passed by the state legislature. Section 13 outlines the requirements for voter id's, including listing the valid types of id that a voter may present, as well as what protocol an election official is to follow if a voter does not present valid identification:
(2)(A) Except as provided in subdivision (b)(2)(B) of this section, if a voter is unable to verify his or her registration when voting in person by presenting a document or identification card that complies with subdivision (b)(1)(A)(i) of this section, the election official shall: (i) Indicate on the precinct voter registration list that the voter did not present a required document or identification card; and (ii) Permit the voter to cast a provisional ballot and inform the voter of the requirements under subdivision (b)(4) of this section.
Under this section a voter is able to cast a provisional ballot, not a regular ballot. For this ballot to count the voter must sign a sworn statement at the polling site, or present a valid form of identification, as outlined in the act, to either the county board of election commissioners or to the county clerk by noon on the Monday following the election. These amendments and the new Act, have addressed the issues which made the 2014 law unconstitutional. However, as shown by the case presented, this Act is not free from controversy. In the case, the Supreme Court focused on: I. Sovereign Immunity; II. Standing; and, III. Preliminary Injunction. Under the sovereign immunity issue, the appellee argued that act 633 violated voters' constitutional right to vote by requiring them to provide identification - and thus creating a barrier to voting - when seeking to place their ballot. The court held that the claim was not subject to the sovereign-immunity defense. The standing issue is based on the grounds that the appelle brings the complaint; the appelle claims that despite owning a valid driver's license which he could present to vote but refused to. The court held that the although appelle did not actually suffer an injury, he has standing because he is a registered voter who is subject to Act 633. The preliminary injunction requires the court to determine whether Act 633 is germane to Amendment 51, the court held that it was. Following this, the court must then decide if the Act is consistent with the Amendment; here the appellee and the court disagree over the interpretation of the Amendment. The court reads the Amendment in the context of the entire Arkansas constitution and determines that Act 633 is an enforcement method for Amendment 51 stating that the purpose of Amendment 51 is: "to ensure that all who cast ballots in elections are legally qualified to vote." Because the court finds that Act is not clearly unconstitutional, the court upholds Act 633. Justice Hart dissents on this opinion, stating that Act 633 is not germane to Amendment 51.
