Arguing that the purpose of Amendment 51 can be read as requiring registration, and that the requirement of showing photo identification when casting a ballot is not within this scope. Furthermore, Hart disagrees with the argument that 'enforcement mechanism' is implied in Amendment 51, rather she argues that the basis for understanding an 'enforcement mechanism' falls not within the text of the Amendment or any reading of it, but rather in a 'penumbra' or shadow that the Amendment casts.

item.title: TEST-Arkansas Supreme Court upholds revised voter I.D. law
item.dc:creator: peckerd
item.content:encoded: The Arkansas Supreme Court has upheld a voter I.D. law that is largely similar to a law that was struck down as unconstitutional in 2014. The ruling came on Thursday in an appeal from a case in the Pulaski County Circuit Court. The plaintiff in that case, Barry Haas, was granted a preliminary injunction based on his complaint about the Act. Act 633 requires voters to "verify" their registration by presenting identification that shows the voter's name and photo. It differs from the act struck down in 2014 only in that voters without such an I.D. now have the option of signing a sworn statement confirming their identities, under penalty of perjury. Haas filed a complaint on February 7, 2018 asking the circuit court to find Act 633 unconstitutional and to enjoin its enforcement. He complained that the Act violated section 19 of amendment 51, and sections 1 and 2 of article 3 of the Arkansas state constitution. The original voter I.D. law from 2014, Act 592, was struck down on similar constitutional grounds. The court ruled that the act's requirement of photo I.D. imposed a requirement that fell outside the four qualifications outlined in article 3. The Court now rules in the opposite direction, stating that Act 633 is "germane" to the requirements set out in article 3. They claim that the photo I.D. requirement is in line with the purpose of amendment 51, which is to ensure that all who cast ballots in elections are legally qualified to vote. In a dissent to the majority opinion, Judge Jo Hart disagreed that the new law was related to the goals of voter registration. He questions why a photo I.D. would be required to verify a registration that did not require one in the first place. The court's decision means that Act 633 will be in place for the upcoming general elections in the state.

item.title: TEST Arkansas Supreme Court upholds voter ID law
item.dc:creator: tdelorenzo
item.content:encoded: On Thursday the Arkansas Supreme Court declared a revised voter ID law constitutional. The law was passed in February 2017 to replace the previous voter ID law that the state's Supreme Court struck down as unconstitutional in 2014. The 5-2 decision clears the way for the state to enforce its strict identification requirements for the upcoming midterm elections in November. The new voter ID law requires a person to show "a document or identification card that shows the person’s name and photograph, is issued by the federal or state government or an accredited postsecondary educational institution in Arkansas, and if displaying an expiration date, is no more than four years expired" in order to cast a ballot. Voters without an ID are permitted to cast a provisional ballot that may be counted if other qualifications are met. The challenge to Arkansas' law argued that the legislature's implementation of the new voter identification requirements was unconstitutional since it amended a statute that only applied to registering to vote, not casting a ballot. The court was unmoved by this argument, stating that although the statute did not expressly apply itself to the physical act of voting, the statute's "broad purpose" of regulating the voting process included the new law. The minority dissent pushed back on this interpretation, stating that the purpose of the legislation clearly limited it to the registration process alone. Thursday's ruling is the latest in a nationwide argument over the validity of voter identification requirements. Last week a federal circuit court in Missouri blocked sections of the state's law, while a different court in Texas recently upheld their identification requirements.

item.title: TEST - Arkansas Supreme Court upholds voter registration law
item.dc:creator: cthompson
item.content:encoded:
The Arkansas Supreme Court decided on Thursday to uphold the state's voter registration law. The court reversed and remanded the Circuit Court's prior preliminary injunction in favor of the plaintiff. This decision overrules a 2014 decision by the court that found Arkansas's voter registration statute unconstitutional.  The current statute dictates that voters must verify their registration by presenting or valid photo ID, or cast a provisional ballot and sign a document verifying their identify on penalty of perjury. The court focused its analysis on Amendment 51 of Arkansas' state constitution, which states:
“No person shall vote or be permitted to vote in any election unless registered in a manner provided for by this amendment."
Associate Justice Wynne, writing for the majority, found that this amendment allowed the state to determine a method for enforcement, and that two methods outlined in the statute--presenting a photo ID or signing a statement--were valid and constitutional. Justice Kemp issued a dissent, joined by Justice Hart, in support of the Circuit Court's injunction. In her dissent, Justice Kemp questioned whether a photo ID necessarily verifies a voter's registration, as a photo ID is not currently required to register to vote. Several states have been evaluating voter registration laws ahead of the upcoming election. On Wednesday, the Missouri Supreme Court ruled to partially block Missouri's voter ID law.

item.title: TEST - Arkansas Supreme Court rules voter ID law constitutional
item.dc:creator: ssundier
item.content:encoded:
On Thursday, the Arkansas Supreme Court upheld the state’s amended voter identification law. The court’s decision is in contrast with its 2014 ruling, which struck down a similar voter ID law. In its new decision, the majority opinion sided with Arkansas Secretary of State, Mark Martin. Justice Robin Wynne penned the opinion, stating that Act 633 falls within the scope of and appropriately amends Amendment 51 of the Arkansas Constitution. The key change in Act 633 is the allowance of provisional ballots for individuals who do not bring voter ID with them to the polls. These voters would be required to either present valid ID to the county board of elections or county clerk by the Monday following election day or to sign a sworn statement:
“stating that the voter is registered to vote and that he or she is the person who is registered. The sworn statement portion of the voter statement is not required to be notarized but the voter shall execute the sworn statement under penalty of perjury…. [The ballot will be] counted contingent upon the verification of the voter's eligibility.”
In dissent, Justice Josephine Linker Hart wrote that she instead agreed with the circuit court's decision, noting that Act 633 is not relevant to Amendment 51. Justice Hart noted that not only is the voter registration process distinct from voting procedure, but the voter registration process itself does not require photo ID. As a result, the requirement for voter ID at time of voting is suspect. The balance between preventing voter fraud and ensuring respect of the 14th and 16th Amendments of the US Constitution has yet to be firmly established. State voter ID laws continue to be a source of debate across numerous US states, including Missouri, Georgia, and North Dakota.

item.title: TEST - ICC Chief Prosecutor issues statement on impending Israeli demolition of Bedouin village
item.dc:creator: tdelorenzo
item.content:encoded: The International Criminal Court's (ICC) Office of the Prosecutor issued a strongly worded statement yesterday rebuking Israel's proposed eviction of a Bedouin community in the West Bank. Chief Prosecutor Fatou Bensouda described the recent escalation of violence as "alarming" and reminded that "extensive destruction of property without military necessity and population transfers in an occupied territory constitute war crimes". Though Israel is not a member of ICC and does not accept its jurisdiction, the ICC has been observing the region since 2015 following the eruption of violence between Israeli and Palestinian forces in the contested territory the year before. The demolition of the village of Khan al-Ahmar has been part of an ongoing controversy in the West Bank, a region of land disputed between Israel and Palestine that has been a major source of tension and violence for more than half a century. In 2013, Israel's Ministerial Committee for Legislation approved a bill that would demolish up to 35 Bedouin villages in the region to make way for Israeli settlements and construction, a move that was widely condemned by the international community. On September 5th, Israel's Supreme Court issued a judgement authorizing the demolition of Khan al-Ahmar. The decision has brought widespread condemnation from many sources, including numerous European countries, UNICEF, and Amnesty International. As of press time, the United States has not issued a statement.

item.title: TEST ICC cautions Israel against potential war crimes
item.dc:creator: cthompson

item.title: TEST - Israel's planned demolition of Bedouin village could constitute war crime, according to ICC
item.dc:creator: peckerd
item.content:encoded: The prosecutor for the International Criminal Court has warned that the Israeli government's planned demolition of the Bedouin village of Khan al-Ahmar could constitute a war crime. In a statement published on Tuesday, ICC prosecutor Fatou Bensouda stated that "extensive destruction of property without military necessity and population transfers in an occupied territory constitute war crimes under the Rome Statute." She also expressed her alarm at "continued violence, perpetrated by actors on both sides, at the Gaza border with Israel." Khan Al-Amar is a village of about 180 Bedouin settlers, including about 90 children, located in Israel's West Bank. It also houses an internationally-funded school which serves around 150 children from the surrounding area. The zone of the West Bank which the village occupies has long been strategically important for Israel as it connects the north and south ends of the West Bank. The Israeli Supreme Court in September upheld the demolition order, rejecting a final set of petitions against the demolition by village residents. Israeli authorities gave the residents of Khan Al-Amar until October 1 to either destroy their own homes or be forcibly evicted. Bensouda in her statement said that "Evacuation by force now appears imminent, and with it the prospects for further escalation and violence." Bensouda's concerns have been echoed by many in the international community. The UK, Spain, Germany, France, and Italy issued a joint statement last month saying that the demolition would threaten the possibility of a single, contiguous Palestinian state, as well as that of a future two-state solution. Bensouda closed her statement by saying that she continues "to keep a close eye on the developments on the ground and will not hesitate to take any appropriate action, within the confines of the independent and impartial exercise of [her] mandate under the Rome Statute, with full respect for the principle of complementarity."

item.title: TEST - ICC warns Israel about potential war crime regarding Bedouin community
item.dc:creator: ssundier
item.content:encoded:
The Chief Prosecutor for the International Criminal Court (ICC), Fatou Bensouda, released a statement on Wednesday stating that the planned eviction for the community of Khan al-Ahmar is being monitored by the ICC’s Office of the Prosecutor.

Khan al-Ahmar is a Bedouin community located on Israel’s West Bank. The community has twelve at-risk sub-divisions, which include an estimated 1,400 residents. These residents have a history of repeated expulsion and re-settlement due to Israeli action. One of these groups is the Jahalin Bedouin, who were evicted from Tel Arad of Negev in 1952 by the Israeli army. Territorial disputes have been an ongoing issue for decades.

The history is further complicated by Israel’s 1969 Land Law, which allows for compensated resettlement to legal government towns. Relocation is problematic, though, given that the Bedouins are nomadic people and that government towns are not structured to accommodate a sudden substantial increase in population.

Israel’s Supreme Court rejected an appeal on September 5th, 2018 to prevent the demolition of the site inhabited by this Bedouin community. Israel’s claim is that Khan al-Ahmar was built illegally, and resettlement is a necessary corrective measure.

In response to Israel’s Supreme Court decision, Palestinian officials filed a war crime claim against Israel with the International Criminal Court, and preliminary examinations of this claim are ongoing.

Bensouda points out in her statement that despite Israel’s Supreme Court ruling, “extensive destruction of property without military necessity and population transfers in an occupied territory constitute war crimes under the Rome Statute.” 

In addition to the ICC, the European Parliament has also criticized Israel’s intentions, “[calling] on the Israeli authorities to immediately halt and reverse their settlement policy," which threatens the Bedouin community and complicates the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

item.title: Tracy Chapman sues Nicki Minaj for copyright infringement---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mbarber
item.content:encoded: Tracy Chapman filed a complaint on Monday alleging copyright infringement by rapper Nicki Minaj. The complaint, filed in the US District Court for the Southern District of California, alleges that Minaj failed to obtain permission before sampling from Chapman's 1988 hit song Baby Can I Hold You. Minaj's song Sorry was reportedly recorded prior to her seeking permission to use Chapman's work. The song was slated to be released on Minaj's August 2018 Album Queen, but was scrapped at the last minute, once it was realized the track included alleged copyrighted material.  The 14-page complaint stated that even though Chapman repeatedly denied all license requests made through their respective managers, Minaj allowed the song to be released. The song was released through a popular New York City disc jockey named Funkmaster Flex. Flex Tweeted his intent to play the track on the radio on August 11, 2018. He subsequently posted a link with the track via an embedded video player (now deleted) on his webpage. The complaint references since-deleted Tweets from Minaj stating she was unaware Sorry included copyrighted work from Chapman. The Tweets allegedly went so far as to publicly plead for Chapman to clear the license for use on the track. In addition to seeking actual or statutory damages, the complaint seeks to permanently enjoin Minaj from using or exploiting the track and to compel her to take reasonable steps to prevent third-parties from using or exploiting the track.
item.category: US District Court for the Southern District of California

item.title: TEST Georgia Appellate rules that Annotations in Georgia’s code cannot be Copyrighted
item.dc:creator: bsige
item.content:encoded: On October 19, 2018, litigation between the State of Georgia and Public.Resource.org, Inc. (Public Resource) was settled in favor of Public Resource. Public Resource is a non-profit website dedicated to the free publication of government records and primary legal sources. Georgia alleges that Public Resource unlawfully distributed the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (OCGA), a body of statutes that contain annotations consisting of commentary, references, and summaries of opinions from the Georgia Attorney General, and other references. In 2013, Public Resource purchased the OCGA and distributed free scans of the text via their website. Georgia claimed that this is in violation of its copyright to the annotations that accompany the statutes. Public Resource argued that the annotations belong in the public domain along side the laws themselves. The Eleventh District Federal Court of Appeals found for Public Resource. In doing so, the court stated that the people of Georgia were the constructive authors of the OCGA. Georgia argued that it was the constructive author of the annotations. Even though Georgia claimed that the annotations were not legally binding, and thus not laws that were made by the people of Georgia via their legislators, the court contended that the OCGA was made by public officials who were paid by tax dollars. The court placed the document in the public domain. The court further states that the annotations were not merely “law-like.” They were “authoritative sources on the meaning of Georgia Statutes” (p. 41). The Georgia General Assembly adopted the annotations along side the text of the statutes when it voted to renew the usage of the OCGA. The court explained that “Georgia courts have cited to the annotations as authoritative sources on statutory meaning” (p. 41). The court also claims that the Georgia law provides that the annotations of the statutory text in the OCGA shall be merged together. State law provides that the merged document is a government document that authoritatively embodies Georgia’s laws. Because of the nature of the text, the annotations have been constructively authored by the people of Georgia. The practical implication of the court’s ruling is that the people of Georgia cannot be forced to pay for access to the annotations in the OCGA.

item.title: TEST: Government Seeks Stay on Impending Census Trial
item.dc:creator: bsige
item.content:encoded: The federal government wants the Supreme Court to block a trial in a case regarding the Trump administration’s attempt to insert a citizenship question for the 2020 census. The government wants to prevent its scheduled November 5 trial until the court has ruled on the government’s petition to limit the trial’s scope. Several states filed suit in New York. They argued that empirical data suggest that the census question would reduce the response rate from certain sectors of the population, thereby decreasing the accuracy of census data. The Trump administration’s purpose in enacting this rule is to reduce the number of undocumented immigrants who are counted towards a state’s population and who therefore contribute, among other things, to the state’s permitted number of representatives and its number of votes in the electoral college. The government argues that the Southern District Court of New York should not have denied the government’s motion to stay the November 5 trial date. The District Court contended that the government had the opportunity to file a motion for summary judgement on September 30, 2018, but elected not to. The Court stated to the government that it would not be barred from making a summary judgement motion but that it would be better off preparing for trial. The Court stated that a trial will be necessary and that the November 5 date should remain set. Because of the Court’s input, the government decided not to prepare to file for summary judgement, opting instead to prepare for trial. The government seeks for the trial to be postponed until the Supreme Court has ruled on whether or not the trial is appropriate in the first place. It contends that the Commerce Department’s ability to perform its constitutional duties would be inhibited by the trial. The District Court permitted the respondent states to “probe the Secretary’s mental processes” by seeking discovery beyond the administrative record. As such, the government seeks to limit the review of the evidence provided by the Secretary of Commerce to the administrative record.

item.title: UN rights experts concerned over racism in Netherlands welfare system---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded: A group of UN human rights experts expressed concern Monday over the prevalence of racism in the Dutch welfare system. According to the experts, police in May forcibly removed seven children of African descent, including an infant that was being breastfed, from their parents' home and have not since allowed visitation. The experts have raised concerns with the government about the treatment of the family and asked that they be reunited and guaranteed equal treatment before the law. They reported a disparity in how the Dutch welfare system treats people of African descent compared to white families. In response the government has denied any racial bias or impropriety and stated that discrimination should be reported to the police and local anti-discrimination services. In a 2014 report, the UN Working Group of Experts on People of African Descent found that racial profiling is still common practice in the Netherlands and a disproportionate number of people of African descent are in conflict with the law, showing further need for the government to pay attention to institutionalized stereotypes of people of African descent. The Netherlands has put in place policies for reporting racial discrimination, but the experts say this is not enough. There are still reports of xenophobia and racism in the media increasing as messages that create fear of minorities lead to incidents of discrimination. Other problems faced by people of African descent include limited access to quality education, lack of appropriate representation in private sector employment as well as in the public sector, especially the judiciary, police and other branches of civil service. The experts suggest that affirmative action policies, as well as more targeted policies should be put in place to promote effective equality of people of African descent in order to address the many issues facing them.

item.title: Palestine brings claim against US over Jerusalem embassy transfer
item.dc:creator: swalker
item.content:encoded: Palestine asserted in an application [text, PDF] submitted to the International Court of Justice (ICJ) on Friday that the recent relocation of the US embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem constitutes a breach of international diplomatic law. In support of its claim, Palestine directed the ICJ to multiple UN General Assembly and Security Council Resolutions affirming the special international regime that applies to Jerusalem and calling on member states to refrain from recognizing Jerusalem as Israeli territory. Palestine argued that the establishment of an embassy to Israel in Jerusalem is contrary to provisions of the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations [text, PDF] governing diplomatic activities "in the receiving state." US President Donald Trump announced [statement] in December that he would allow the Jerusalem Embassy Act [text, PDF] to take effect for the first time since its passage in 1995. Trump criticized his predecessors for blocking implementation of the law and instructed State Department officials to begin the process of transferring the US Embassy to Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. The new embassy opened [press statement] on May 14, 2018, the 70th anniversary of the Israeli Declaration of Independence [text]. In the application submitted Friday, Palestine asked the ICJ to declare the US in breach of the Vienna Convention and to order the withdrawal of the American embassy from Jerusalem.

item.title: Federal judge rules congressional Democrats may pursue Trump emoluments lawsuit
item.dc:creator: tbrown
item.content:encoded: A judge for the US District Court for the District of Columbia [official website] ruled [opinion, PDF] Friday that Democratic members of Congress may sue President Donald Trump over alleged violations of the Foreign Emoluments Clause [Cornell LII backgrounder] of the Constitution. Under the Foreign Emoluments Clause, federal officials, including the president, are not allowed to accept any foreign "present, Emolument, Office, or Title" without permission from Congress. The congressional Democrats filed suit [JURIST report] last year, alleging "that the President 'has a financial interest in vast business holdings around the world that engage in dealings with foreign governments and receive benefits from those governments.'" Because of this financial interest, they claim that the president has and will continue to accept emoluments from foreign states. They further allege that "because the President has denied them the opportunity to give or withhold their consent, he has injured them in their roles as Members of Congress." The judge did not make any ruling on whether Trump violated the Foreign Emoluments Clause. The judge found only that the congressional Democrats have standing and are therefore able "to sue the President for allegedly violating the Foreign Emoluments Clause." In July, a federal judge allowed a separate lawsuit [JURIST report] under the Emoluments Clause to proceed.

item.title: California governor signs net neutrality bill into law; DOJ responds with lawsuit
item.dc:creator: tbrown
item.content:encoded: California Governor Jerry Brown signed a net neutrality bill [materials] into law Sunday, drawing an immediate lawsuit [complaint, PDF] from the US Department of Justice (DOJ) [official site]. The suit alleges [press release] that the bill "unlawfully imposes burdens on the Federal Government's deregulatory approach to the Internet." US Attorney General Jeff Sessions said that "[u]nder the Constitution, states do not regulate interstate commerce—the federal government does. Once again the California legislature has enacted an extreme and illegal state law attempting to frustrate federal policy." In its complaint, the DOJ is seeking a preliminary injunction in order to invalidate the law, saying that it is "preempted by federal law and therefore violates the Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution."

item.title: Egypt court orders retrial of Muslim Brotherhood leader Mohamed Badie
item.dc:creator: akoltonowski
item.content:encoded: An Egyptian court on Sunday ordered the retrial of Muslim Brotherhood [BBC profile] leader Mohamed Badie and other prominent members from the group after new evidence arose from a February 2015 ruling. State news agency MENA reported [Al Jazeera report] that the retrial relates to a case in which "Badie and 14 others were handed life sentences for incitement to commit murder and attempted murder of anti-Muslim Brotherhood demonstrators near the group's headquarters in June 2013." Badie, the Brotherhood's spiritual leader, had previously been sentenced to death after Egypt's military removal of President Mohamed Morsi [BBC profile] and is embroiled in nearly 40 other trials. Since the removal of Morsi hundreds of members have been sentenced to death in a crackdown on the now-outlawed Brotherhood. While it is unclear exactly why charges were modified, Egyptian law allows charges to be altered if new evidence arises. The new charges involve "premeditated murder, attempted murder, beating to death and possession of unlicensed weapons, MENA reported." The retrial affects only those in custody and not those defendants who were tried in absentia. The retrial is set to begin October 7.

item.title: Federal appeals court upholds New York nuclear energy subsidy law
item.dc:creator: eslobe
item.content:encoded: The US Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit [official website] on Thursday upheld [opinion, PDF] New York's Zero Emissions Credit (ZEC) program, which provides subsidies to specific nuclear power plants in New York for being greenhouse gas-emission free sources of energy. In the first two years of the program, the FitzPatrick, Ginna and Nine Mile Point nuclear power plants received ZEC of $17.48 per MWh of electricity the plants generated. The cost is paid by local utilities based on their proportional share of the state's total electric load. Utilities may also purchase the ZECs directly from the nuclear power plants. The lawsuit against the ZEC program was brought by several electrical generators and electricity generation trade groups. The plaintiffs argued that the law violated the Constitution because the law is preempted by the Federal Power Act and because the law violates the dormant Commerce Clause. The courts have previously found that states have the right to regulate production. However, they cannot affect interstate rates, which is the jurisdiction of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC). This is the line that Congress has determined, and the court acknowledged that "New York has kept the line in sight, and gone as near as can be without crossing it." The law was found to be allowable because the ZEC apply at the production of electricity "regardless of whether or how the electricity is ultimately sold." The law does not set a certain wholesale price and does not replace the NYISO auction price for electricity. The court also found FERC allows states to subsidize facilities for environmental or policy reasons, even if they have an indirect effect on wholesale electricity prices. The Commerce Clause challenge to the law was dismissed by the court. The plaintiffs did not show an injury that could be redressed by a favorable decision. The plaintiffs argued that the law favored New York nuclear power plants that would be given unfair competition in the interstate market. However, because none of the plaintiffs operate nuclear power plants out of the state, the plaintiffs' injuries would continue even if New York gave the subsidies to out of state nuclear power plants. The US Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit upheld [JURIST report] a similar ZEC law in Illinois in September. The Illinois ZECs were enacted [JURIST report] by law in December 2016. The lawsuit was filed [JURIST report] against the Illinois law in February 2017.

item.title: Macedonia voters approve name change in referendum with low turnout
item.dc:creator: mmarotta
item.content:encoded: A referendum in Macedonia to change the country's name to "The Republic of North Macedonia" garnered a 94.2 percent "yes" vote Sunday, but only 36.8 percent of eligible voters cast their ballots. Despite the low turnout, Prime Minister Zoran Zaev accepts [press release, in Macedonian] the result and says he and the government will move forward with bringing the issue to Parliament. Macedonia, which lies between Balkan and Hellenistic influence, has been contested for many years. Recently it has attempted to accede to the EU, but the name change is a prerequisite for EU membership. "I urge all political leaders & parties to engage constructively & responsibly to seize this historic opportunity," said [tweet] Jens Stoltenberg, Secretary-General of NATO. "NATO's door is open, but all national procedures have to be completed." Macedonia is so named because of a 1993 UN Security Council Resolution [materials] that officially severed it from the disintegrating Yugoslavia and established its independence. In 2007 neighboring Greece announced [press release, in Greek] that it would only cooperate with Macedonia if the name is changed erga omnes (the incorporation of the term "Macedonia" in the name, but with the use of a disambiguating name specification, for international and intergovernmental use). Soon afterward UN Moderator Matthew Nimetz proposed several different names, all of which Macedonia rejected. Now, with a name change as a prerequisite to join the EU, some Macedonian citizens support changing the name while others retain pride in the current name.

item.title: California enacts law to erase old marijuana convictions
item.dc:creator: eslobe
item.content:encoded: California Governor Jerry Brown [official website] signed [press release] a bill [text] Sunday that would allow past marijuana convictions to be recalled or dismissed if the conviction would no longer violate the law due to the passage of the Control, Regulate and Tax Adult Use Marijuana Act (AUMA). AUMA legalized, among other things, possession of up to 28.5 grams of cannabis and up to 8 grams of concentrated cannabis for those who are 21 or older. AB-1793 will require the Department of Justice to review state criminal history in order to determine which past convictions would no longer be illegal under AUMA and would be eligible for recall or dismissal. The eligible convictions are required to be identified before July 1, 2019. Prosecutors will then have until July 1, 2020, to review and raise challenges against the eligible convictions. A challenge can be raised if the prosecutor finds that the conviction is not eligible, or if the person "presents an unreasonable risk to public safety." The public defender's office will notify those who's convictions are being challenged. The courts will be required to reduce or dismiss the convictions that don't receive any challenges by July 1, 2020. The state summary criminal history database will then be updated within 30 days. Any costs that are experienced by local agencies or school districts due to this law will be reimbursed by the state. The law was approved [JURIST Report] by the California State Legislature in August. Several laws have been passed in recent years to legalize the use of marijuana around the world. Manhattan District Attorney announced in September that they will be dropping [JURIST report] 3,042 marijuana charges in New York City. South Africa's Constitutional Court decriminalized [JURIST report] personal use of marijuana in September. In June, Canada's Senate passed [JURIST report] a law that would legalize recreation use of marijuana.

item.title: Supreme Court opens term with arguments in two cases
item.dc:creator: elowman
item.content:encoded: The US Supreme Court [official website] heard oral arguments in two cases on Monday, marking the beginning of its 2018 term. At issue in Weyerhaeuser Company v. United States Fish and Wildlife Service [SCOTUSblog materials] is whether the Endangered Species Act [text] forbids an agency to designate private property as an "unoccupied critical habitat" if the land is not essential to species conservation. There is also a question of whether the judiciary can review this agency decision if it was motivated by economic interest. The petitioner, the lessee of the land, argued [transcript, PDF] that the government should not designate the area as a "critical habitat" because the species in question, the dusky gopher frog, had not inhabited the area for decades. The government said that restoring the area is "essential" to help conserve the species. The second case, Mount Lemmon Fire District v. Guido [SCOTUSblog materials], deals with whether the Age Discrimination in Employment Act [text] exempts state and local government employers with less than 20 employees. The respondent, a former firefighter, sued the local fire department for alleged age discrimination after his termination. The fire department claimed that it was exempt from the ADEA. Most of the debate centered [transcript, PDF] on the language of the statute.

item.title: Federal judge allows rejected Florida ballots to be counted---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lwinkels
item.content:encoded: A judge for the US District Court for the Northern District of Florida ruled Thursday that thousands of ballots rejected for mismatched signatures must be counted. Florida law allows county election officials to reject vote-by-mail and provisional ballots due to mismatched signatures. This is a significant portion of voters—in the 2016 general election more than 2.7 million Florida voters either voted or attempted to vote by mail. Judge Mark Walker ruled in favor of Bill Nelson and the Democratic Executive Committee, granting their motion for preliminary injunction and denying Republican Secretary of State Ken Detzner's motion to stay the injunction. Walker held that under Rule 65 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure; the plaintiffs had established irreparable injury, that the injunction was in the public interest - "The right of voters to cast their ballots and have them counted is guaranteed in the constitution." - and that Florida's statutory scheme unconstitutionally burdens the right of  citizens to vote and have their vote counted. The Court stated that "without procedural safeguards, the use of signature matching is not reasonable and may lead to unconstitutional disenfranchisement." because the system of signature matching does not have a standard for determining the validity of the signature, and that those who are making these decisions are laypeople without any training in handwriting analysis. Going through the affirmative defenses raised by the Defendant, the Court systematically disproves each defense; the equitable doctrine of laches does not bar relief in this case, the doctrine of res judicata does not apply and does not bar the plaintiffs' claims, and the case of Toney v. White does not hold as persuasive in the current case. In closing, the Court argues that the system of counting provisional and vote-by-mail ballots in Florida is unconstitutional and that it places a higher burden on the voters. They hold that the county supervisors are to allow voters who should have had the opportunity to correct their ballots are able to do so now, before the second official results are fully counted.

item.title: European contact lens supplier Vision Direct reports data theft---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mbarber
item.content:encoded: UK contact lens giant, Vision Direct, announced a major data hack on Monday that compromised personal and financial details of some of its online customers. The hack occurred between 12:11 AM, November 3rd and 12:52 PM, November 8th and affected customers who logged into the Vision Direct Website during those times. Vision Direct describes the scope of the hack as such that only affected incoming data on the website during the affected times and not the company's overall database of customer information. Online sources claim that the hack was completed through a javascript keylogger that tracked users' keystrokes. The script enabled hackers to monitor user keystrokes to record user information which "includes full name, billing address, email address, password, telephone number and payment card information, including card number, expiry date and CVV," according to the company's statement. Vision Direct recommends for any customers who logged in and entered any personal or financial information during the time of the hack to contact their respective banks or credit card providers for instructions on how best to protect themselves. Both Ticketmaster and British Airways have released similar statements after experiencing similar hacks in recent months.

item.title: Airbnb to halt services in Israeli West Bank---HOLD
item.dc:creator: khall
item.content:encoded:
Airbnb, the person-to-person room renting service, announced on Monday that it will stop listing properties in the disputed territories of the Israeli occupied West Bank. Up until this point, users were free to list properties in the disputed territories like anywhere else. Airbnb's previous approach was that it would operate as far as U.S. law allows, which places no specific restrictions regarding doing business within these regions. In a press release, Airbnb explained that it decided to take a different approach after careful scrutiny of the issue and factoring in the company's social obligations.
We are most certainly not the experts when it comes to the historical disputes in this region. Our team has wrestled with this issue and we have struggled to come up with the right approach...we spent considerable time speaking to various experts — including those who have criticized our previous approach — about this matter. As a global platform operating in 191 countries and regions and more than 81,000 cities, we must consider the impact we have and act responsibly...When we applied our decision-making framework, we concluded that we should remove listings in Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank that are at the core of the dispute between Israelis and Palestinians.
The decision will impact approximately 200 properties currently listed in the region. Airbnb has provided no information regarding when such properties will be removed from the platform.

item.title: Egypt creates Human Rights Commission to defend government from abuses---HOLD
item.dc:creator: tzubizarreta
item.content:encoded: Monday, Egypt has created a new High Permanent Commission for Human Rights to defend the government from accusations of human rights abuses. The government has been accused of various human rights abuses after the arrests, torture, and disappearances of numerous lawyers, political activists, and journalists. Human Rights Watch, a nongovernmental human rights organization, released a report last week which showed that at least 40 individuals were arrested since late October. Many of them had been involved in providing humanitarian and legal support to the families of current detainees. The new commission's purpose is not to curtail human rights abuses, but to defend the government from accusations of abuse particularly on the world stage. The new commission does not include any human rights activists. Its representatives mostly come from existing government positions including the military, intelligence agencies, the foreign ministry, or the interior ministry. The interior ministry, in particular, oversees a police force which has been accused of torture and forced disappearances. The new commission will defend the Egypt's actions internationally as necessary "rights" to protect the state from "terrorism".

item.title: EU highest court hears Brexit challenge---HOLD
item.dc:creator: xshi
item.content:encoded: The Court of Justice of the European Union on Tuesday begun assessing whether Britain can unilaterally reverse its decision about leaving the EU, as British Prime Minister Theresa May struggled to contain criticism of the Brexit deal from U.K. politicians and U.S. President Donald Trump. The Brexit deal, which was approved on Sunday by EU leaders, needs to be approved by the UK Parliament on 11 December, but its approval is far from guaranteed since Labour, the Lib Dems, the SNP, the DUP and many Conservatives MPs are set to vote against it. Opponents of the deal, including May's former defense secretary, Michael Fallon, said the deal will keep the UK too closely tied to EU rules and make it harder to strike future trade deals with other countries and minimise their value. May's argument that the deal "delivered for the British people" and set the UK "on course for a prosperous future" by continuing to adhere to EU rules and standards in many areas was also challenged by the US President Donald Trump. Trump said that the agreement seemed like a “great deal for the EU” and “right now, if you look at the deal, they may not be able to trade with us, and that wouldn’t be a good thing.” May replied to Trump by insisting that “as regards the United States, we have already been talking to them about the sort of agreement that we could have in the future, we have a working group set up and that is working very well, has met several times and is continuing to work with the U.S. on this.” The court decision could be made as close as the Britain's leave date on March 29, 2019. If the Parliament reject the deal, the leave date may have to be pushed back to give negotiators the time to make major improvements to the agreement.

item.title: West Virginia Supreme Court refuses to force governor to move to capital---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mborges
item.content:encoded: The West Virginia Supreme Court this month rejected a proposal from Democratic Delegate Isaac Sponaugle to force Governor Jim Justice to live in Charleston. The two paragraph rejection of the proposal was unanimously decided by the Court. The proposal was based on Article VII-7-1 of the West Virginia state constitution stating that the Governor and other executive authorities of the state are to reside in Charleston, the seat of government, during their terms. Sponaugle contends that the Governor has only spent "a handful of nights" at the mansion. Justice has stated that he lives in Lewisburg, WV but regularly uses the Governor's mansion in compliance with the constitution.  In response to the petition, Justice's lawyers questioned the meaning of the word "reside" and asserted that Justice is in Charleston often enough to be an effective Governor. The lawsuit was previously dismissed by Kanawha Circuit Court on a technicality. Sponaugle said that he intends to bring the issue to the Circuit Courts. Justice Tim Armstead recused himself from the case as he had been temporarily appointed to serve on the Court by Justice.

item.title: Washington Supreme Court adopts new standard of employer knowledge in Microsoft retaliation case---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ssundier
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court of Washington disagreed with Microsoft on Thursday about the appropriate standard of knowledge employers should have when faced with retaliation claims. The court ruled that the knew-or-suspected standard for knowledge, which is favorable to employees bringing claims against their employers, should be applied to employee discrimination cases. This standard was adopted due to a retaliation claim against Microsoft. While an employee at Microsoft, Cornwell (the plaintiff) had filed a lawsuit against her supervisor. After this lawsuit, Cornwell changed work groups to avoid further interactions with him. Despite this, she later encountered a situation that would have required her to interact with this supervisor again. To explain why she could not work with him, Cornwell notified her new supervisors about the existence of the lawsuit. Soon after relaying this information, Cornwell was rated as a poor performer. Despite this rating being inconsistent with her evaluation feedback, the low performance score led to her subsequent lay-off. To determine if there was a causal link between Cornwell's lawsuit and her termination by Microsoft, the court needed to decide whether Cornwell's new supervisors had "sufficient knowledge that she had taken a protected action under Washington Law Against Discrimination (WLAD), RCW 49.60.030." Microsoft advocated that the court should use the actual knowledge standard, while Cornwell argued the knew-or-suspected standard would be appropriate. The court sided with Cornwell, defining and broadly adopting the knew-or-suspected standard. The knew-or-suspected standard is notable because it can be applied when an employer has knowledge about the existence of a complaint or lawsuit but only a suspicion regarding the complainant. Any adverse actions based on this suspicion are sufficient to demonstrate a causal link for retaliation. The court found that Cornwell's case easily met the threshold for this test. Adopting this standard is a significant coup for employees because it helps close a loophole for retaliatory behaviors. This decision is consistent with WLAD's overarching purpose of protecting employees from the effects of discrimination and retaliation.

item.title: Wisconsin legislature rescinds power for new Dem governor and
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded:
In an abrupt about face, the Republican majority Wisconsin legislature rescinded executive powers it granted to Governor Scott Walker, and Attorney General (AG) Brad Schimel in 2010, which will now limit the powers of Governor elect Tony Evers and AG elect Josh Kaul, both Democrats. Consider Act 21 which gave Governor Walker the power to veto or approve rules promulgated by state agencies, this has now been rescinded and the power has reverted back to the legislature for final decision as proposed in Senate Bill 887  The bill also includes provisions that allow, pass through entities, individuals, partnerships and corporations can elect to be taxed. AG elect is specifically limited by a provision that states; The bill also provides that when a party challenges the constitutionality of a  statute, facially or as applied, or challenges a statute as violating or preempted by  federal law, as part of a claim or affirmative defense, the assembly, the senate, and  JCLO have the right at any time to intervene and participate in the action and may  also retain legal counsel other than DOJ. Under the bill, the Committee on Assembly  Organization may intervene in the action, as well as obtain legal counsel, on behalf  of the assembly; the Committee on Senate Organization may intervene in the action,  as well as obtain legal counsel, on behalf of the senate; and JCLO may intervene in 
the action, as well as obtain legal counsel, on behalf of the state. If JCLO determines  that the interests of the state will be best represented by special counsel appointed  by the legislature, JCLO must appoint special counsel to represent the state  defendants and act instead of the attorney general. In these circumstances, special  counsel has the powers of the attorney general with respect to the litigation to which  special counsel has been appointed. In an interview with reporters after the November election Assembly Speaker Robin Vos is reported to have said "If there are areas where we could look and say, 'Geez — have we made mistakes where we granted too much power to the executive,' I'd be open to taking a look to say what can we do to change that to try to re-balance it,"  Governor elect Evers has said, "I view this as a repudiation of the last election. I will take any steps possible to assure the people of Wisconsin that I will not invalidate those votes."

item.title: North Carolina Board of Elections releases documents in mail-in ballot tampering probe---HOLD
item.dc:creator: emccarthy
item.content:encoded: The North Carolina State Board of Elections released evidentiary documents Wednesday pertaining to claims of irregularities and fraudulent activities related to absentee by-mail voting in the state's 9th US Congressional District just outside of Charlotte. Republican Mark Harris leads Democrat Dan McCready by just over 900 votes. The Board announced on Friday it has delayed certifying results of the race. Several residents within the 9th district reported instances of volunteers coming to their houses to help fill out absentee ballots, offering to pick up the ballots and send them, but not doing so. In addition, numbers that do not seem right have set off several red flags. For example, Harris is ahead in Bladen County at 61 percent of mail-in ballots, while only 19 percent of the voters who requested vote-by-mail were registered Republican. While any qualified voter in a statewide primary, general or special election may vote absentee in North Carolina, it is a felony for someone who is not the voter or the voter's "near relative" to return an absentee ballot, to or assist a voter to vote an absentee ballot under the correct absentee voting procedure. Chairman of the State Board of Elections & Ethics Enforcement Joshua Malcolm issued a letter this week directing agency staff to "review and post materials associated with the investigation into election processes in certain counties within the 9th Congressional District." "The State Board has long sought to promote public confidence in elections through the transparent production of official records and extensive public data when disclosure is possible without undermining the integrity of ongoing investigations or prematurely exposing sources," Malcolm wrote. Evidence and materials that will not "undermine the investigation or prematurely expose sources" can be accessed online, including a list generated by the Statewide Elections Information Management System reflecting all civilian voters in the 9th Congressional District to whom a ballot was sent, but from whom a ballot was not returned during the 2018 general election, absentee ballot return envelopes and ballot return logs for various counties, among others. Dan McCready said in a statement following the Board's decision, "The right to vote is the foundation of our democracy. Any effort to rob a person of that right should be met with the full force of justice." A public evidentiary hearing is set for on or before December 21.

item.title: NC approves voter ID bill
item.dc:creator: xshi
item.content:encoded: North Carolina state Senate on Thursday ratified a bill requiring voters offering to vote in person present photo identification before casting ballots at the polls. Before passing the bill, the state only asks voters to state their name and current address to the election official and sign his or her name to the poll book, other voting record, or voter authorization document prior to voting. The bill requires the State Board to adopt a rule to include identification in the request for an absentee ballot by mail. Voters may instead include the required identification with their returned ballot. In addition to voter ID requirements, the bill also mandates the creation of a new Class I felony for counterfeiting, selling, lending to, or knowingly permit the unauthorized use of a form of photo identification for the purpose of voting. "This guarantees that one of the most precious rights that we have - the right to vote - is maintained, protected, and expanded, and at the same time safeguards are in place to eliminate the chance of fraud." Tim Moore said on the floor of the state House during debate.

item.title: Ireland moves forward with bill removing blasphemy from Constitution
item.dc:creator: tzubizarreta
item.content:encoded:
The Justice Minister of Ireland Charlie Flanagan is reportedly seeking to fast-track the repeal of the offence of blasphemy through the Irish Cabinet. JURIST previously reported in October on the referendum for the people of Ireland to vote on a Constitutional Amendment repealing blasphemy from the constitution. That referendum passed and was signed into law by the president in November. With the law passed and the constitution modified the government of Ireland now looks to the practical implementation of this. The Justice Minister Charlie Flanagan is seeking leave from the Cabinet to publish the General Scheme of Repeal of Offence of Publication or Utterance of Blasphemous Matter Act 2018. This act would remove the criminal punishment for blasphemy from Section 36 and Section 37 of the Defamation Act of 2009. The criminal offence would be removed and the Irish Justice system would no longer be able to prosecute the offence. Ordinarily, these proposals would have to go through the standard legislative process and review. The Justice Minister however is asking to fast-track these changes stating:
The minister’s thinking is that the Scheme of the Bill reflects the decision taken by the people in the referendum, the Bill is short and not particularly complex, and it would be difficult to justify any significant delay in bringing forward the necessary legislative proposals given the vote of the Irish people.
The memo sent to the Cabinet asks to avoid the typical pre-legislative scrutiny. It will be up to the Cabinet to grant this request or not. For more thoughts on the matter, check out the commentary piece by Pearl Goldman on JURIST.

item.title: UK Supreme Court rules Scotland partly overstepped its lawmaking bounds with Brexit bill
item.dc:creator: mborges
item.content:encoded: The UK Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that Scotland's Parliament partially overstepped their constitutional bounds in passing a Brexit bill. The EU Withdrawal Act would ensure that Scotland retains its rule-making powers once the UK leaves the European Union. The British government requested in April that the Supreme Court review this rule to ensure that its enactment would not cause legal confusion. Areas of the Scottish law concerning "agriculture, fisheries and food standards and labeling" are currently governed by the EU, those powers would devolve back to Britain after Brexit. Scotland seeks the ability to consent to laws the UK makes about Brexit. It is only that section that was struck down by the court.  A speaker for the Scottish government asserted that the bill only has domestic effects and will not affect the UK's negotiations with the EU. The bill provided that its provisions don't take effect until the time that Brexit occurs. Additionally it has provisions to prevent its application when in conflict with UK and EU law. The bill remains on the books to prepare Scotland for the withdrawal of the UK from the EU. A majority of Scotland voted to remain in the EU and are unhappy with Theresa May's Brexit plans.

item.title: ICJ rules Bolivia cannot force Chile to grant 'sovereign access' to Pacific Ocean
item.dc:creator: mmarotta
item.content:encoded: The International Court of Justice ruled [judgment, PDF] on Monday that landlocked Bolivia cannot force neighboring, coastal Chile to grant it access to a portion of the Pacific Ocean Chile presently controls. "The Court is unable to conclude, on the basis of the material submitted to it, that Chile has the obligation to negotiate with Bolivia in order to reach an agreement granting Bolivia a fully sovereign access to the Pacific Ocean," reads the judgement. Chile and Bolivia have long contested access to the Pacific Ocean; Bolivia controlled a portion of coast until 1904, when Chile successfully annexed the territory. The day has since been commemorated each year by grieving Bolivians, and the nation has attempted to renegotiate water rights for over 100 years. The ICJ first agreed [JURIST report] to hear this case in 2015 after both parties asserted that through the 1948 Pact of Bogotá [text], the ICJ had agreed to hear all cases regarding Pacific Ocean rights. As part of his most recent bid to gain water rights, Bolivian President Evo Morales suggested giving Chile an equal portion of Bolivian territory in exchange for some coastline, but Chile rejected the offer. In a press release [text, in Spanish] on Monday afternoon, the government affirmed that "the seas and oceans are the common heritage of humanity and in their immensity can only be compared to the Bolivian desire to return to the sea." "Our demand can not and should not be considered as an unfriendly act but as the opportunity that allows us to rediscover ourselves," said Morales. "We are neighbors and brothers with a common destiny."

item.title: California governor signs bill requiring companies to include women on boards
item.dc:creator: rmoore
item.content:encoded:
California Governor Jerry Brown [official website] signed a bill [text] into law on Sunday that will require public corporations to include more women on their boards of directors. State Senators Toni Atkins and Hannah-Beth Jackson [official websites] introduced [ABC News report] Senate Bill 826, citing a report that one-fourth of California's companies have no women sitting on their boards. According to their research, achieving gender parity would be impossible without government intervention. The California Chamber of Commerce [official website] and several other business groups argued [NPR report] that the bill was unconstitutional because it does not consider other forms of diversity and attempts to manage the corporate boards of companies incorporated in a different state. The bill states:
(a) No later than the close of the 2019 calendar year, a publicly held domestic or foreign corporation whose principal executive offices, according to the corporation’s SEC 10-K form, are located in California shall have a minimum of one female director on its board. A corporation may increase the number of directors on its board to comply with this section.
(b) No later than the close of the 2021 calendar year, a publicly held domestic or foreign corporation whose principal executive offices, according to the corporation’s SEC 10-K form, are located in California shall comply with the following:
(1) If its number of directors is six or more, the corporation shall have a minimum of three female directors.
(2) If its number of directors is five, the corporation shall have a minimum of two female directors.
(3) If its number of directors is four or fewer, the corporation shall have a minimum of one female director.
Any company that fails to meet these requirements will be fined [NYT report] $100,000 for their first violation of the law. California is the first state to make gender inclusivity a requirement of corporate boards.

item.title: US to deny visas to unmarried same-sex partners of foreign diplomats
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded:
The Trump administration on Monday began to implement its new policy [memo, PDF] of denying visas to unmarried, same-sex partners of foreign diplomats and employees of the UN. The G-4 Visa [US Legal backgrounder] is used for family members of foreigners working in the US on behalf of a foreign government or international agencies. The visa also allows for family members of the foreigner to study while in the US. The new policy provides:
Currently accredited same-sex domestic partners of United Nations officials who wish to maintain their G-4 visa must be ready to submit proof of marriage by 31 December 2018. After 31 December 2018, they will be expected to leave the United States within 30 days unless they submit the required proof of marriage or have obtained separate authorization to remain in the country through a change of non-immigrant status.
The Trump administration has stated [USA Today report] that the new policy is more in line with existing policy that does not allow unmarried opposite-sex partners to participate in the visa program. However, the shift is controversial as many countries do-not allow same-sex marriage.

item.title: UK PM announces civil partnerships for all couples
item.dc:creator: arundell
item.content:encoded: UK Prime Minister Theresa May [official website] announced [Tweet] Tuesday that all couples will now have the choice to enter into a civil partnership rather than to get married. May stated [BBC report] that allowing this union for all couples was necessary since some individuals "want to formalize their relationship but don't necessarily want to get married." This change stems from a decision [judgment, PDF] by the Supreme Court in June, which that found a heterosexual couple was allowed to enter into a civil partnership. The court ruled [JURIST report] that the Civil Partnership Act 2004 was incompatible with the European Convention on Human Rights. The couple at the center of the debate has since posted a video [BBC report] expressing their excitement to move forward in a civil partnership.

item.title: Federal judge allows lawsuit challenging North Carolina 'bathroom bill' to proceed
item.dc:creator: khall
item.content:encoded: A judge for the US District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina [official website] ruled [order, PDF] Sunday that a lawsuit against North Carolina's new "bathroom bill," which prohibits local governments from enacting new anti-discrimination laws regarding multiple occupancy restrooms, can move forward. The case was originally brought by a group of transgender individuals challenging the state's 2016 "bathroom bill," House Bill 2 (HB2) [text, PDF]. HB2 was repealed [JURIST report] last year after facing a number of legal challenges and subsequently replaced by current restrictions under House Bill 142 (HB142) [text, PDF]. HB142 effectively requires all anti-discrimination laws pertaining to multiple occupancy restrooms to be passed through the state government. In issuing the order, Judge Thomas Schroeder dismissed the plaintiffs' Due Process, Title IX and Title VII claims arising under the new law which were alleged to result from the uncertainty transgender individuals have faced as to which restrooms they are legally allowed to use in light of the law. Schroeder, however, allowed the suit to continue on Equal Protection grounds, stating that "[w]hile HB142 does not prohibit Plaintiffs' efforts at advocacy, it plainly makes them meaningless by prohibiting even the prospect of relief at the local level."

item.title: US, Canada agree to replace NAFTA with new trade deal
item.dc:creator: mmarotta
item.content:encoded: The US and Canada signed a new trade deal Monday to replace the 24-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). "Late last night, our deadline, we reached a wonderful new Trade Deal with Canada," tweeted [text] US President Donald Trump on Tuesday morning, "to be added into the deal already reached with Mexico. The new name will be The United States Mexico Canada Agreement, or USMCA." The USMCA [text] includes 34 chapters and contains new tariff schedules, labor laws, and rules on which products can legally be imported or exported, including updated settlements and protections on textiles, agriculture, and digital trade. It was written to last at least 16 years with review for renewal to take place every six years. In a press release [text], Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said "the agreement-in-principle we reached today is good for Canada, good for Canadian businesses, and most importantly, good for Canadian workers and their families." Trump has sought to replace NAFTA since he took office last year. In August he signed [JURIST report] a separate deal with Mexico, but negotiations with Canada took a month longer. On Tuesday morning the Canadian dollar jumped to a five-month high and the Mexican peso to a seven-week high.

item.title: UK PM announces tight visa restrictions as part of Brexit
item.dc:creator: mmarotta
item.content:encoded: British Prime Minister Theresa May announced Tueday that after Brexit, visa priority will be given to high-skilled workers while low-skilled workers may be barred from working in the country. The report [text, PDF] was originally filed on September 18, but May announced it to the public this morning. It includes salary thresholds for different kinds of labor and calls for a temporary ban to be placed on new low-skilled migrant worker visas. "For lower-skilled workers, we do not see the need for a work-related scheme with the possible exception of a seasonal agricultural workers scheme," the proposal says. The proposal will add extra security measures for people entering the country, even short-stay tourists, and even successful "high-skill" applicants must be first sponsored by future employers. The proposal will not cap the number of new student visas. Throughout Tuesday many British business organizations decried the announcement. The Confederation of British Industry announced [press release] "every day workers with skills the UK needs are turned away and jobs left unfilled. Employers all over the UK will continue to urge its abolition to show the world Britain means business." In December 2017 the European Commission announced [text, PDF] that despite Brexit, most foreign workers of any skill level would remain protected under EU law, from which May's newest proposal seeks to divorce itself. If this proposal is enacted current migrant workers will not have their status changed, but future migrant workers may be barred from working in the UK.

item.title: Supreme Court declines to hear Tennessee abortion case
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded: The US Supreme Court [official website] on Monday declined to hear [order list, PDF] an appeal from a group of Tennessee voters regarding Amendment 1 [text, Section 36, PDF] to the state's constitution, a 2014 ballot measure that eliminated the right to an abortion from the document. The petitioners argued that the vote counting method was fundamentally unfair and skewed the voting in support of the amendment. The court's decision allows the ruling [JURIST report] from the US Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit [official website], which upheld the constitutionality of the voting method, to stand. Tennessee Attorney General Herbert Slatery III [official profile] supported [press release] the court's decision not to review the case under the contention that "a state, and not a federal court should decide how votes are counted under its own Constitution" and that 72,000 votes in favor of the amendment should stand.

item.title: Supreme Court hears arguments in capital punishment case
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded:
The US Supreme Court [official website] heard oral arguments [transcript, PDF] Tuesday over whether the state can execute an individual who suffers from dementia and cannot remember the crime. Madison v. Alabama [docket] is before the Supreme Court for a second time. This time, the court seeks to answer the question [text, PDF]: "[c]onsistent with the Eighth Amendment ... may the State execute a prisoner whose mental disability leaves him without memory of his commission of the capital offense?" 67-year-old Vernan Madison suffers from vascular dementia, which caused him to have several strokes. As a result, he is unable to remember commissioning the crime for which he is sentenced to death. Madison was scheduled face the death penalty in May 2016, but he challenged the sentence under Alabama's competency-to-be-executed statute. Alabama courts found that Madison did not meet the incompetency standard under the statute because he is not insane or psychotic, but the US Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit disagreed. The "majority found that the evidence undisputably established that Mr. Madison had no memory of the offense and ... that he was incompetent to be executed." The Supreme Court reversed the holding, saying the appeals court had no authority to decide the merits of the evidence of the case. This time, the Supreme Court only heard arguments to decide whether execution of an individual with Madison's mental disability violates the eighth amendment. The petitioner argued that a person who is unable to remember the commission of a crime due to a diagnosed mental disability, rather than unexplainable memory loss, is incompetent to face execution. The petitioner explained this distinction in her argument, saying:
Here, we know that Mr. Madison's brain is damaged.  We can see it on an MRI.  We know that his cognitive disabilities have declined. We know that he is not able to understand the things going on around him. And we argued that, because of that dementia, which has very particular features, he is incompetent to be executed.
The respondent countered, saying, "there is absolutely no objective evidence of a national consensus supporting" a rule that the state may execute a person who does not remember commissioning a capital offense. Also Tuesday the US Supreme Court [official website] heard oral arguments [transcript] in a case challenging the federal Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act (SORNA) [text]. Gundy v. US [docket] begs answers to two primary questions [text] resulting from SORNA's delegation authority to the Attorney General (AG): "[w]hether convicted sex offenders are "required to register" under [SORNA] while in custody, regardless of how long they have until release; and "[w]hether all offenders convicted of a qualifying sex offense prior to SORNA's enactment are "required to register" under SORNA no later than August 1, 2008." The petitioner, Herman Grundy, specifically challenges SORNA's delegation provision, saying it "grants unguided power to the nation's top prosecutor to expand the scope of criminal laws and to impose burdensome, sometimes lifetime registration requirements on hundreds of thousands of individuals." The statute refers to SORNA as a "comprehensive national system for the registration of [sex] offenders" but does not indicate that the statute applies retroactively to individuals convicted prior to the statute's enactment. Justice Neil Gorsuch summarized the petitioner's argument, saying:
[T]he specific statutory section dealing with pre-enactment offenders says unambiguously that the Attorney General decides whether, how, when, and who, even who. So you don't even know if you're going to be subject to this law ... And ... I'm having trouble thinking of another delegation in which this Court has ever allowed the chief prosecutor of the United States to write the criminal law for those he's going to prosecute. [This Court] say[s] that vague criminal laws must be stricken. [This Court] just repeated that last term. What's vaguer than a blank check to the Attorney General of the United States to determine who he's going to prosecute?
The respondent countered the argument, saying the statute provides for guidance in governing pre-statute offenders and vests the authority with the AG: "[The AG's] job is to get as many of the existing offenders who fall into that universe into the registries as you can, recognizing there are going to be some practical barriers. [He is] going to have to specify the applicability of the requirements."

item.title: Human rights groups call on Europe to save rescue ship Aquarius
item.dc:creator: eslobe
item.content:encoded: Several human rights groups called [text] upon European leaders on Wednesday to offer registration to the rescue ship Aquarius. The human rights groups that signed the letter include Amnesty International, European Council on Refugees and Exiles, the Human Rights Watch, International Commission of Jurists and International Federation for Human Rights [advocacy websites]. Aquarius is a rescue ship operated by SOS Mediterranee and Médécins Sans Frontières (MSF). It operates in the Mediterranean Sea and rescues those who become stranded attempting to cross the sea. It is the last nongovernmental ship that operates in the sea. If it does not receive a new registration, the ship will be forced to stop operations. The ship's registration was removed by Panamanian authorities due to pressure from the Italian government. The human rights groups have called the Aquarius necessary to provide "potentially life-saving assistance to vulnerable people at risk, including injured people, pregnant women, torture survivors, people traumatized by shipwrecks and unaccompanied minors." In total, an estimated 1,260 people have already died or gone missing off the coast of Libya. The groups call not registering Aquarius "tantamount to endorsing a deliberate strategy to obstruct legitimate humanitarian assistance to human beings at risk of drowning in international waters off Europe’s coasts." The Mediterranean Sea has been a dangerous path for refugees for many years. In October 2017 the UN Refugee Agency announced [JURIST report] 3,740 people died attempting to cross the sea so far that year. In August 2015 the International Organization for Migration announced [JURIST report] more than 2,000 lives were lost by that point in the year attempting to cross the sea. Italy has previously accused [JURIST report] SOS Mediterranee and other non-governmental organizations in April 2017 of colluding with Libya-based human smugglers. In September Italy's cabinet approved [JURIST report] a bill that would make it easier for the country to deport migrants.

item.title: Federal judge allows forced labor lawsuit against Tesla to continue
item.dc:creator: eslobe
item.content:encoded: A judge for the US District Court for the Northern District of California [official website] refused [opinion, PDF] Monday to dismiss two forced labor claims against Tesla [corporate website] in a lawsuit filed by two former workers. The former workers worked for subcontractor Vuzem, who worked for Eisenmann, which manufactures specialized paint shop equipment. Eisenmann installed equipment at Tesla, Mercedes-Benz, Deere & Company, LaX Fabricating, REAHU, Volkswagen and BMW. The plaintiffs specifically worked on installing a paint shop at Tesla's facility in Fremont, California. The plaintiffs were hired on B-1 visas and came from Slovenia and Croatia. The lawsuit alleges that the plaintiffs were forced to work more than 250 hours per month, received one in 14 days off and were paid under minimum wage. The lawsuit also alleges that Vuzem threatened to withhold medical benefits, visas, pay and immigration benefits if they were two sick to work or reported a job injury. The lawsuit named 36 defendants, eight of which were involved in the current motion to dismiss. Claims that the defendants violated the False Claims Act, violated minimum wage and overtime provisions, violated the Fair Labor Standards Act, and violated Alabama forced labor laws were dismissed against all eight defendants. Claims that the defendants violated Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act (TVPRA) and California Civil Code § 52.5 was dismissed against six defendants, but allowed against Tesla and Eisenmann. The judge found that the alleged immigration threats, financial threats, litigation threats and  threats to withhold medical care were sufficient to make a claim under TVPRA. Although Vuzem is the only one accused of making the threats, Tesla and Eisenmann knew or should have known about the mistreatment of the workers. Therefore, Tesla and Eisenmann would also be liable. Telsa and Eisenmann were found to be liable under California's forced labor law § 52.5 because it has the same basis for liability as TVPRA. Tesla has also faced a class action lawsuit [JURIST report] filed in April 2017 over the car's self driving function, which was alleged to be "essentially unusable and demonstrably dangerous." Self-driving cars [JURIST op-ed] have faced an uncertain regulatory future as federal and state governments attempt to develop regulations on the industry,

item.title: ICJ orders US to lift Iran sanctions on 'humanitarian' goods
item.dc:creator: khall
item.content:encoded:
The International Court of Justice (ICJ) [official website] ruled [order, PDF] on Wednesday that the US must lift its sanctions on the Islamic Republic of Iran that affect imports of humanitarian goods as well as products and services linked to the safety of civil aviation. The US sanctions against Iran were reimposed in May and August [JURIST reports] after President Donald Trump withdrew the US from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (commonly referred to as the Iran Nuclear Deal). In July Iran brought suit [JURIST report] against the US in the ICJ alleging that the sanctions violate a 1955 bilateral agreement known as the US-Iran Treaty of Amity [text, PDF]. In its unanimous decision, the ICJ held that:
the United States, in accordance with its obligations under the 1955 Treaty, must remove, by means of its choosing, any impediments arising from the measures announced on 8 May 2018 to the free exportation to the territory of Iran of goods required for humanitarian needs, such as (i) medicines and medical devices; and (ii) foodstuffs and agricultural commodities; as well as goods and services required for the safety of civil aviation, such as (iii) spare parts, equipment and associated services (including warranty, maintenance, repair services and safety-related inspections) necessary for civil aircraft. To this end, the United States must ensure that licences (sic) and necessary authorizations are granted and that payments and other transfers of funds are not subject to any restriction in so far as they relate to the goods and services referred to above.
However, the ICJ refused to grant Iran's call for sweeping measures against other US sanctions and ordered both parties to refrain from any action that might aggravate or extend the dispute.
